witList.witness: Broughton in BM copy of Robinson
Collier in BM copy of Dyce

opener.salute:
TO MY WORTHY FRIEND,
MR. THOMAS HAMMON,
OF GRAYES INNE, &c.

div1.p:
This Play, composed by composedby so worthy an Authour as Master Marlo;
and the part of the Jew presented by so unimitable inimitable an Actor as
Master Mr. Allin, being in this
later latter Age commended to the Stage: As
I usher'd it unto the Court, and presented it to the Cock-pit, with
these Prologues and Epilogues here inserted, so now being newly
brought to the Presse, I was loath it should be published without
the ornament of an Epistle; making choyce of you unto whom to
devote it; then whom (of all those Gentlemen and acquaintance,
within the compasse of my long knowledge) there is none more
able to taxe Ignorance, or attribute right to merit. Sir, you have bin
pleased to grace some of mine owne workes with your curteous
patronage; I hope this will not be the worse accepted, because
commended by mee; over whom, none can clayme more power or
privilege than your selfe. I had no better a New-yeares gift to
present you with; receive it therefore as a continuance of that
inviolable obliegement, by which, he rests still ingaged; who as he
ever hash, shall alwayes remaine,

div1.head: The Prologue spoken at Court.
div1.l: Gracious and Great, that we so boldly dare,
('Mongst other Playes that now in fashion are)
To present this; writ many yeares agone,
And in that Age, thought second unto none;
We humbly crave your pardon: we pursue
The story of a rich and famous Jew
Who liv'd in Malta: you shall find him still,
In all his projects, a sound Machevill;
And that's his Character: He that hath past
So many Censures, is now come at last
To have your princely Eares ; , grace you him , ; then ,
You crowne the Action, and renowne the pen.

div2.head: Epilogue.
div2.l: It is our feare (dread Soveraigne) we have bin
Too tedious; neither can't be lesse than sinne
To wrong your Princely patience: If we have,
(Thus low dejected) we your pardon crave:
And if ought here offend your eare or sight,
We onely Act, and Speake, what others write.

div1.head: The Prologue to the Stage, at the Cocke-pit.
div1.l: We know not how our Play may passe this Stage,
But by the best ofMarlo Poets in that age
The Malta Jew had being, and was made;
And He, then by the best ofAllin Actors play'd:
In Hero and Leander, one did gaine
A lasting memorie: in Tamberlaine Tamerlane ,
This Jew, with others many , : th'other wan
The Attribute of peerelesse, being a man
Whom we may ranke with (doing no one wrong)
Proteus for shapes, and Roscius for a tongue,
So could he speake, so vary; nor is't hate
To merit : inPerkins him who doth personate
Our Jew this day, nor is it his ambition
To exceed, or equall, being of condition
More modest; this is all that he intends,
(And that too, at the urgence of some friends)
To prove his best, and if none here gaine-say it,
The part he hath studied, and intends to play it.

div2.head: Epilogue.
div2.l: In Graving, with Pigmalion to contend;
Or Painting, with Apelles; doubtlesse the end
Must be disgrace: our Actor did not so,
He onely aym'd to goe, but not out-goe.
Nor thinke that this day any prize was plaid,
Here were no bests at all, no wagers laid;
All the ambition that his mind doth swell,
Is but to heare from you, (by me) 'twas well.

sp.l: Albeit the world thinke thinks Machevill is dead,
Yet was his soule but flowne beyond the Alpes,
And now the Guize is dead, is come from France
To view this Land, and frolicke with his friends.
To some perhaps my name is odious,
But such as love me, yard me from their tongues,
And let them know that I am Machevill,
And weigh not men, and therefore not mens words . :
Admir'd I am of those that hate me most : .
Though some speake openly against my bookes,
Yet will they they will reade me, and thereby attaine
Are poyson'd by my climing followers.
I count Religion but a childish Toy
And hold there is no sinne but Ignorance
Birds of the Aire will tell of murders past;
Many will talke of Title to a Crowne : .
What right had Caesar to the Empery Empire ?
Might first made Kings, and Lawes were then most sure
When like the Dracos Drancus they were writ in blood.
Hence comes it, that a strong built Citadell
Commands much more then letters can import:
Which maxime had had butD (qy) Phaleris observ'd,
H'had never bellowed in a brasen Bull
Of great ones envy; o'th poore petty wites,
Let me be envy'd and not pittied!
But whither am I bound, I come not, I,
To reade a lecture here to you hereD2 (qy) in Britanie Britaine ,
But to present the Tragedy of a Jew,
Who smiles to see how full his bags are cramb'd ,
Which mony was not got without my meanest
I crave but this, Grace him as he deserves,
And let him not be entertain'd the worse
Because he favours me.

div2.head: Act One, Scene One
div2.stage: Enter Barabas in his Counting-house, with heapes of gold before him.

sp.l: So that of thus much that returne was made:
And of the third part of the Persian Persian ships,
There was the venture summ'd and satisfied.
As for those Samnites Samintes Sabans Saenites ScenitesRg and the men of Uzz

That bought brought my
Spanish
Oyles, and Wines of Greece,
Here have I purst their paltry silverlings silverbings silverings silverlings .
Eye; what a trouble tis to count this trash.

Well fare the
Arabians
who so richly pay ,
The things they traffique for with wedge of gold,
Whereof a man may easily in a day
Tell that which may maintaine him all his life.
The needy groome that never fingred groat,
Would make a miracle of thus much coyne:
But he whose steele-bard coffers are cramb'd full,
And And he who all his life time hath bin tired,
Wearying Wearing his fingers ends with telling it,
Would in his age be loath to labour so,
And for a pound to sweat himselfe to death:

Give me the Merchants of the
Indian
Mynes,
That trade in mettall of the purest mould;
The wealthy Moore, that in the Easterne rockes
Without controule can picke his riches up,

And in his house heape pearle pearls
like pibble-stones , ;
Bags of fiery Opals, Saphires, Amatists,
Jacints, hard Topas, grasse-greene Emeraulds,
Beauteous Rubyes, sparkling Diamonds,
And seildsene costly stones of so great price,
As one of them indifferently rated,
And of a Carrect of this quantity quality ,
May serve in perill of or calamity
To ransome great Kings from captivity.
This is the ware wherein consists my wealth:
And thus me thinkes should men of judgement frame
Their meanes of traffique from the vulgar trade,
And as their wealth increaseth, so inclose
Infinite riches in a little roome.
But now how stands the wind?
Into what corner peeres my Halcions bill?
Ha, to the East? yes: See how stands stand the Vanes?
East and by-South: why then I hope my ships
I sent for Egypt and the bordering Iles
Are gotten up by Nilus winding bankes:
Mine Argosie from Alexandria,
Loaden with Spice and Silkes, now under saile,
Are smoothly gliding downe by Candie shoare
To Malta, through our Mediterranean sea.
But who comes heare? How now.

sp.speaker:
1. Merchant
Merchant
sp.l:
Thy ships are safe,
riding in Malta Rhode:

And all the Merchants
with other Merchandize

Are safe arriv'd,
and have sent me to know

Whether your selfe
will come and custome them.
The ships are safe thou saist, and richly fraught.

sp.speaker:
1. Merchant
Merchant
sp.l: They are.
Why then goe bid them come ashore,
And bring with them their bils of entry:
I hope our credit in the Custome-house
Will serve as well as I were present there.
Goe send 'um threescore Camels, thirty Mules,
And twenty Waggons to bring up the ware.
But art thou master in a ship of mine,
And is thy credit not enough for that?

sp.speaker:
1. Merchant
Merchant
sp.l: The very Custome barely comes to more
Then many Merchants of the Towne are worth,
And therefore farre exceeds my credit, Sir.
Goe tell 'em the Jew of Malta sent thee, man:
Tush, who amongst amougst 'em knowes not Barrabas?

sp.speaker:
1. Merchant
Merchant
sp.l: I goe.
So then, there's somewhat come.
Sirra, which of off my ships art thou Master of?

sp.speaker:
1. Merchant
Merchant
sp.l: Of the Speranza, Sir.
And saw'st thou not
Mine Argosie at Alexandria?

Thou couldst not come from Egypt, or by
Caire Cairo
But at the entry there into the sea,
Where Nitus payes his tribute to the maine , .
Thou needs must saile by Alexandria.

sp.speaker:
1. Merchant
Merchant
sp.l: I neither saw them, nor inquir'd of them.
But this we heard some of our sea-men say,
They wondred how you durst with so much wealth
Trust such a crazed crazy Vessell, and so farre.
Tush , ; they are wise ; . I know her and her strength:
But By Bye goe, goe thou thy wayes, discharge thy Ship,
And bid my Factor bring his loading in.
And yet I wonder at this Argosie.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant.
sp.l: Thine Argosie from Alexandria,

Know Barabas ,
cloth ride in Malta Rhode , .
Laden with riches, and exceeding store
Of Persian silkes, of gold, and Orient Perle.
How chance you came not with those other ships
That sail'd by Egypt?

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: Sir we saw 'em not.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Belike they coasted round by Candie shoare
About their Oyles, or other businesses.
But 'twas ill done of you to come so farre
Without the ayd or conduct of their ships.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: Sir, we were wafted by a Spanish Fleet
That never left us till within a league,
That had the Gallies of the Turke in chase.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh they were going up to Sicily:
Well, goe
And bid the Merchants and my men dispatch
And come ashore, and see the fraught freight discharg'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: I goe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thus trowles our fortune in by land and Sea,
And thus are wee on every enery side inrich'd:
These are the Blessings promis'd to the Jewes,
And herein was old Abrams happinesse:
What more may Heaven doe for earthly man men
Then thus to powre out plenty in their laps,
Ripping the bowels of the earth for them,
Making the Sea seas their servant servants Q, Dd2 + , and the winds
To drive their substance with successefull blasts?
Who hateth me but for my happinesse?
Or who is honour'd now but for his wealth?
Rather had I a Jew be hated thus,
Then pittied in a Christian poverty:
For I can see no fruits in all their faith,
But malice, falsehood, and excessive pride?
Which me thinkes fits not their profession.
Happily some haplesse man hath conscience,
And for his conscience lives in beggery.
They say we are a scatter'd Nation:
I cannot tell, but we have scambled scrambled up
More wealth by farre then those that brag of faith.
There's Kirriah Jairim, the great Jew of Greece,
Obed in Bairseth, Bairseth in Portugall,
My selfe in Malta, some in Italy,
Many in France, and wealthy every one:
I, wealthier farre then any Christian.
I must confesse we come not to be Kings:
That's not our fault: Alas, our number's few,
And Crownes come either by succession,
Or urg'd by force; and nothing violent,
Oft have I heard tell, can be permanent.
Give us a peacefull rule, make Christians Kings,
That thirst so much for Principality.
I have no charge, nor many children,
But one sole Daughter, whom I hold as deare
As Agamemnon did his Iphigen:
And all I have is hers. But who comes here?
Tush, tell not me 'twas done of policie.
Come therefore let us goe to Barrabas;
For he can counsell best in these affaires;
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why, how now Countrymen?
Why flocke you thus to me in multitudes?
What accident's betided to the Jewes?
A Fleet of warlike Gallyes, Barabas,
Are come from Turkey, and lye in our Rhode:
And they this day sit in the Counsell-house
To entertaine them and their Embassie.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why let 'em come, so they come not to warre;
Or let 'em warre, so we be conquerors:

l.seg: Nay let 'em combat, conquer, and kill all,
So they spare me, my daughter, and my wealth.

sp.l: Were it for confirmation of a League,
They would not come in warlike manner thus.
I feare their comming will afflict us all.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Fond men, what dreame you of their multitudes ?
What need they treat of peace that are in league?
The Turkes and those of Malta are in league.
Tut, tut, there is some other matter in't.
Why, Barabas, they come for peace or warre.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Happily for neither, but to passe along
With whom they have attempted many times,
But never could effect their Stratagem.
And very wisely sayd, it may be so.
But there's a meeting in the Senate-house,
And all the Jewes in Malta must be there.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Umh; All the Jewes in Malta must be there?
I, like enough, why then let every man
Provide him, and be there for fashion-sake.
If any thing shall there concerne our state

Assure your selves I'le looke —
unto my selfe unto'tDd3 (qy) .
I know you will; well brethren let us goe.
Let's take our leaves; Farewell good Barabas.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Doe so
; Farewell Zaareth farewell Temainte.
And Barabas now search this secret out.
Summon thy sences, call thy wits together togethre :
These silly men mistake the matter cleane.
Long to the Turke did Malta contribute;
Which Tribute all in policie, I feare,
The Turkes have Turk has let increase to such a summe,
As all the wealth of in Malta cannot pay;
And now by that advantage thinkes, belike,
To seize upon the Towne: I, that he seekes.
How ere the world goe, I'le make sure for one of one ,
And seeke in time to intercept the worst,
Warily yarding that which I ha got.

l.foreign: Ego mihimet sum semper proximus proximas .

sp.l: Why let 'em enter, let 'em take the Towne.

div2.head: Act One, Scene Two
div2.stage: Enter [Ferneze] Governor of Malta, Knights [and Officers,] met by [Callapine and other] Bassoes of the Turke; Calymath.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now Bassoes, what demand you at our hands?

sp.speaker: Basso
sp.l:
Know Knights of
Malta
, that we came come from Rhodes ,
From Cyprus, Cyprus, and those other Iles
That lye betwixt the Mediterranean seas.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What's Cyprus, Cyprus, and those other Iles
To us, or Malta? What at our hands demand ye?

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: The ten yeares tribute that remaines unpaid.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Alas, my Lord, the summe is overgreat,
I hope your Highnesse will consider us.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l:
I wish, grave Governour ,
'twere in my power
To favour you, but 'tis my fathers cause,
Wherein I may not, nay I dare not dally.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then give us leave, great Selim-Calymath.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Stand all aside, and let the Knights determine,
And send to keepe our Gallies under-saile,
For happily we shall not tarry here:

Now Governour ,
how say how are you resolv'd?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Thus: Since your hard conditions are such
That you will needs have ten yeares tribute past,
We may have time to make collection
Amongst the Inhabitants of Malta for't.

sp.speaker: Basso
sp.l: That's more then is in our Commission.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l:
What Callapine ,
a little curtesie.
Let's know their time, perhaps it is not long;
And 'tis more Kingly to obtaine by peace
Then to enforce conditions by constraint.
What respit aske you Governour?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: But a month.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: We grant a month, but see you keep your promise.
Now ranch our Gallies backe againe to Sea,
Where wee'll attend the respit you have sane,
And for the mony send our messenger.
Farewell great Governor, and brave Knights of Malta.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: And all good fortune wait on Calymath.
Goe one and call those Jewes of Malta hither:
Were they not summon'd to appeare to day ? .

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: They were, my Lord, and here they come.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: Have you determin'd what to say to them?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l:
Yes, give me leave, and
Hebrews Hebwres
now come neare.
From the Emperour of Turkey is arriv'd
Great Selim-Calymath, his Highnesse sonne,
To levie of us ten yeares tribute past,
Now then here know that it concerneth us — :

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Then good my Lord, to keepe your quiet still,
Your Lordship shall doe well to let them have it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Soft Barabas, there's more longs too't than so.
To what this these ten yeares tribute will amount
That we have cast, but cannot compasse it
By reason of the warres, that robb'd our store;
And therefore are we to request your ayd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Alas, my Lord, we are no souldiers:
And what's our aid against so great a Prince?

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: Tut, Jew, we know thou art no souldier;
Thou art a Merchant, and a monied man,
And 'tis thy mony, Barabas, we seeke.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: How, my Lord, my mony?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Thine and the rest.
For to be short, amongst you 'tmust be had.

sp.speaker: 1. Jew
sp.l: Alas, my Lord, the most of us are poore!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then let the rich increase your portions.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Are strangers with your tribute to be tax'd?

sp.speaker: 2. Knight
sp.l: Have strangers leave with us to get their wealth?
Then let them with us contribute.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: How, equally?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Jew, like infidels.
For through our sufferance of your hatefull lives,
Who stand accursed in the sight of heaven,
These taxes and affiictions are have befal'ne,
And therefore thus we are determined;
Reade there the Articles of our decrees.

sp.speaker: Reader
sp.p:
First, the tribute mony of the Turkes shall all be levyed
amongst the Jewes, and each of them to pay one halfe of his
estate.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
How, halfe his estate?
I hope you meane not mine.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Read on.

sp.speaker: Reader
sp.p:
Secondly, hee that denies to pay, shal straight become a
Christian.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
How ,
a Christian? Hum, what's here to doe?

sp.speaker: Reader
sp.p: Lastly, he that denies this, shall absolutely lose al he has.

sp.speaker: All 3 Jewes.
sp.p: Oh my Lord we will give halfe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Oh earth-mettall'd villaines, and no Hebrews born!
And will you basely thus submit your selves
To leave your goods to their arbitrament?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Why Barabas wilt thou be christened christned ?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: No, Governour, I will be no convertite.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Then pay thy halfe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why know you what you did by this device?
Halfe of my substance is a Cities wealth.
Governour, it was not got so easily;
Nor will I part so slightly therewithall.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir, halfe is the penalty of our decree,
Either pay that, or we will seize on all.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Corpo di dio deo ; stay, you shall have halfe the half ,
Let me be us'd but as my brethren are.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Jew, thou has denied the Articles
And now it cannot be recall'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Will you then steale my goods
Is theft the ground of your Religion?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Jew, we take particularly thine
To save the wine of a multitude:
And better one want for a the common good,
Then many perish for a private man:
Yet Barrabas we will not banish thee,
But here in Malta, where thou gotst thy wealth,
Live still; and if thou canst, get more.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Christians; what, or how can I multiply?
Of nought is nothing made.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: From nought at first thou camst to little welth,
From little unto more, from more to most:
If your first curse fall heavy on thy head,
And make thee poore and scorn'd of all the world,
'Tis not our fault, but thy inherent sinne.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What? bring you Scripture to confirm your wrongs?
Preach me not out of my possessions.
Some Jewes are wicked, as all Christians are:
But say the Tribe that I descended of
Were all in generall cast away for sinne,
Shall I be tryed by their transgression?
The man that dealeth righteously shall live:
And which of you can charge me otherwise?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Out wretched Barabas,

Sham'st thou not thus
to justifie thy selfe,

As if we knew not
thy profession?
If thou rely upon thy righteousnesse,
Be patient and thy riches will increase.
Excesse of wealth is cause of covetousnesse:
And covetousnesse, oh 'tis a monstrous sinne.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, but theft is worse: tush, take not from me then,
For that is theft; and if you rob me thus,
I must be forc'd to steale and compasse more.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: Grave Governor Governors Q, Dd2- , list listen not to his exclames:
Convert his mansion to a Nunnery,
His house will harbour many holy Nuns.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: It shall be so: now Officers have you done?

sp.speaker: Officers
sp.l: I, my Lord, we have seiz'd upon the goods
And wares of Barabas, which being valued
Amount to more then all the wealth in Malta.
And of the other we have seized halfe.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then wee'll take order for the residue.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Well then my Lord, say, are you satisfied?
You have my goods, my mony, and my wealth,
My ships, my store, and all that I enjoy'd;
And having all, you can request no more;
Unlesse your unrelenting flinty hearts
Suppresse all pitty in your stony breasts,
And now shall move you to bereave my life.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Barabas, to staine our hands with blood
Is farre from us and our profession.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why I esteeme the injury farre lesse,
To take the lives of miserable men,
Then be the causers causes of their misery.

You have my wealth ,
the labour of my life,
The comfort of mine age, my childrens hope,
And therefore ne're distinguish of the wrong.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Content thee, Barabas, thou hast nought but right.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Your extreme right does me exceeding wrong:
But take it to you i'th devils name.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Come, let us in, and gather of these goods
The mony for this tribute of the Turke.

sp.speaker: 1 Knight
sp.l: Tis necessary that be look'd unto:
For if we breake our day, we breake the league,
And that will prove but simple policie.

div2.stage: Exeunt. [Manent Barabas and the three Jewes.]

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, policie? that's their profession,
And not simplicity, as they suggest.
The plagues of Egypt, and the curse of heaven,
Earths barrennesse, and all mens hatred

Inflict upon them, thou great
Primus Primas Motor.
And here upon my knees, striking the earth,
I banne their soules to everlasting paines
And extreme tortures of the fiery deepe,
That thus have dealt with me in my distresse.

sp.speaker: 1. Jew
sp.l: Oh yet be patient, gentle Barabas.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh silly brethren, borne to see this day!
Why stand you thus unmov'd with my laments?
Why weepe you not to thinke upon my wrongs?
Why pine not I, and dye in this distresse?

sp.speaker: 1. Jew
sp.l: Why, Barabas, as hardly can we brooke
The quell handling of our selves in this:
Thou seest they have taken halfe our goods.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why did you yeeld to their extortion ?
You were a multitude, and I but one,
And of me onely have they taken all.

sp.speaker: 1. Jew
sp.l: Yet brother Barabas remember Job.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What tell you me of Job? I wot his wealth
Was written thus: he had seven thousand sheepe,
Three thousand Camels, and two hundred yoake
Of labouring Oxen, and five hundred
Shee Asses: but for every one of those these ,
Had they beene valued at indifferent rate,
I had at home, and in mine Argosie
And other ships that came from Egypt last,
As much as would have bought his beasts and him,
And yet have kept enough to live upon;
So that not he, but I may curse the day,
Thy fatall birth-day, forlorne Barabas;
And henceforth wish for an eternall night,
That clouds of darkenesse may inclose my flesh,
And hide these extreme sorrowes from mine eyes:
For onely I have toyl'd to inherit here
The months of vanity and losse of time,
And painefull nights have bin appointed me.

sp.speaker: 2. Jew
sp.l: Good Barabas be patient.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, Ay, , I,

Pray leave me in my patience. You
that

Were
ne're possess of wealth, are pleas'd with want.
But give him liberty at least to mourne,
That in a field amidst his enemies,
Doth see his souldiers slaine, himselfe disarm'd,
And knowes no meanes of his recoverie:
I, let me sorrow for this sudden chance,
'Tis in the trouble of my spirit I speake;
Great injuries are not so soone forgot.

sp.speaker: 1. Jew
sp.l: Come, let us leave him in his irefull mood,
Our words will but increase his extasie.

sp.speaker: 2 Jew
sp.l: On then: but trust me 'tis a misery
To see a man in such affliction:
Farewell Barabas.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, fare you well.
See the simplicitie of these base slaves,
Who for the villaines have no wit themselves,
Thinke me to be a senselesse lumpe of clay
That will with every water wash to dirt:
No, Barabas is borne to better chance,
And fram'd of finer mold then common men,
That measure nought but by the present time.
A reaching thought will search his deepest wits,
And cast with cunning for the time to come:
For evils are apt to happen every day .
But whither wends my beauteous Abigall?
Oh what has made my lovely daughter sad ?
What , ? woman, moane not for a little losse:
Thy father has enough in store for thee.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Father, for thee lamenteth Abigaile:
But I will learne to leave these fruitlesse teares , .
And urg'd thereto with my afflictions,
With fierce exclaimes run to the Senate-house,
And in the Senate reprehend them all,
And rent their hearts with tearing of my haire,
Till they reduce redressD2 (qy) the wrongs done to my father.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, Abigail, things past recovery
Are hardly cur'd with exclamations.
Be silent, Daughter, sufferance breeds ease,
And time may yeeld us an occasion
Which on the sudden cannot serve the turne.
Besides, my girle, thinke me not all so fond
As negligently to forgoe so much
Without provision for thy selfe and me.
Ten thousand Portagues Portagues besides great Perles,
Rich costly Jewels, and Stones infinite,
Fearing the worst of this before it fell,
I closely hid.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Where father?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
In my house ,
my girle.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Then shall they ne're be seene of Barrabas:
For they have seiz'd upon thy house and wares.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: But they will give me leave once more, I bow,
To goe into my house.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: That may they not:
For there I left the Governour placing Nunnes,
Displacing me; and of thy house they meane
To make a Nunnery, where none but their owne sect
Must enter in; men generally barr'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: My gold, my gold, and all my wealth is gone.
You partiall heavens, have I deserv'd this plague?

What ,
will you thus oppose me, lucklesse Starres,
To make me desperate in my poverty?
And knowing me impatient in distresse
Thinke me so mad as I will hang my selfe,
That I may vanish ore the earth in ayre,
And leave no memory that e're I was.
No, I will live; nor loath I this my life:
And since you leave me in the Ocean thus
To sinke or swim, and put me to my shifts,
I'le rouse my senses, and awake my selfe.
Daughter, I have it: thou perceiv'st the plight
Wherein these Christians have oppressed me:
Be rul'd by me, for in extremitie
We ought to make barre of no policie.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Father, what e're it be to injure them
That have so manifestly wronged us,
What will not Abigall attempt?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Then thus ; , thou toldst me they have turn'd my house
Into a Nunnery, and some Nuns are there.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Then Abigall, there must my girle
Intreat the Abbasse to be entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: How, as a Nunne?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, Daughter, for Religion
Hides many mischiefes from suspition.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I, but father they will suspect me there.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Let 'em suspect, but be thou so precise
As they may thinke it done of Holinesse.
Intreat 'em faire, and give them friendly speech,
And seeme to them as if thy sinnes were great,
Till thou hast gotten to be entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Thus father shall I much dissemble.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Tush,
As good dissemble that thou never mean'st meant'st
As first meane truth, and then dissemble it,
A counterfet profession is better
Then unseene unforeseen hypocrisie.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Well father, say say that I be entertain'd,
What then shall follow?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: This shall follow then;
There have I hid close underneath the plancke
That runs along the upper chamber floore,
The gold and Jewels which I kept for thee.
But here they come; be cunning Abigall

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l:
Then father ,
goe with me.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, Abigeal, in this
It is not necessary I be seene.
For I will seeme offended with thee for't.
Be close, my girle, for this must fetch my gold.

div2.stage: Enter two three Fryars and three two Nuns [, one the Abbasse].

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: Sisters,
We now are almost at the new made Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Abbasse
sp.l: The better; for we love not to be seene:
'Tis thirtie 30 winters long since some of us
Did stray so farre amongst the multitude.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: But, Madam, this house
And waters cloistersB (qy) quarters of this new made Nunnery
Will much delight you.

sp.speaker: Abbasse
sp.l: It may be so: but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Grave Abbasse, and you happy Virgins , Virgin's Virgins' D+ (-Ri) guide,
Pitty the state of a distressed Maid.

sp.speaker: Abbasse
sp.l:
What art thou ,
daughter?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: The hopelesse daughter of a haplesse Jew,
The Jew of Malta, wretched Barabas;
Sometimes Sometime the owner of a goodly house,
Which they have now turn'd to a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Abbasse
sp.l: Well, daughter, say, what is thy suit with us?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Fearing the afflictions which my father feeles,
Proceed from sinne, or want of faith in us,
I'de passe away my life in penitence,
And be a Novice in your Nunnery,
To make attonement for my labouring soule.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: No doubt, brother, but this proceedeth of the spirit.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: I, and of a moving spirit too, brother; but come,
Let us intreat she may be entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Abbasse
sp.l: Well, daughter, we admit you for a Nun.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: First let me as a Novice learne to frame
My solitary life to your streight lawes,
And let me lodge where I was wont to lye . ,
I doe not doubt by your divine precepts
And mine owne industry, but to profit much.

l.seg: As much I hope as all I hid is worth.

sp.speaker: Abbasse
sp.l: Come daughter, follow us.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why how now Abigall, what mak'st thou
Amongst these hateful Christians?

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: Hinder her not, thou man of little faith,
For she has mortified her selfe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: How, mortified!

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: And is admitted to the Sister-hood.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Child of perdition, and thy fathers shame,
What wilt thou doe among these hatefull fiends?
I charge thee on my blessing that thou leave
These divers, and their damned heresie.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Father, give forgive me—

l.seg: Nay backe, Abigall,
And thinke upon the Jewels and the gold,
The boord is marked thus thus marked that covers it.
Away accursed from thy fathers sight.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar.
sp.l: Barabas, although thou art in mis-beleefe,
And wilt not see thine owne afflictions,
Yet let thy daughter be no longer blinde.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Blind, Fryer, I wrecke not thy perswasions.

l.seg: The boord is marked thus that covers it,

sp.l: For I had rather dye, then see her thus.
Wilt thou forsake mee too in my distresse,

Seduced Daughter, Goe ,
forget not net .Aside to her.
Becomes it Jewes to be so credulous,

l.seg: To morrow early I'le Il'e be at the doore.

sp.l: No come not at me, if thou wilt be damn'd,
Forget me, see me not, and so be gone.

l.seg: Farewell, Remember to morrow morning.

sp.l: Out, out thou wretch.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Whose this? Faire Abigall the rich Jewes daughter
Become a Nun ? , her fathers sudden fall
Has humbled her and brought her downe to this:
Tut, she were fitter for a tale of love
Then to be tired Out with Orizons:
And better would she farre become a bed
Embraced in a friendly lovers armes,
Then rise at midnight to a solemne masse.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Why how now Don Mathias, in a dump?

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Beleeve me, Noble Lodowicke, I have seene
The strangest sight, in my opinion,
That ever I beheld.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: What west I prethe?

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: A faire young maid scarce fourteene 14 yeares of age,
The sweetest flower in Citherea's field,
Cropt from the pleasures of the fruitfull earth,
And strangely metamorphis'd Nun to a nun a nun .

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: But say, what was she?

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l:
Why ,
the rich Jewes daughter.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l:
What ,
Barabas, whose goods were lately seiz'd?
Is she so faire?

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: And matchlesse beautifull;
As had you seene her 'twould have mov'd your heart,
Tho countermin'd countermur'd Coll with walls of brasse, to love,
Or at the least to pitty.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: And if she be so faire as you report,
'Twere time well spent to goe and visit her:
How say you, shall we?

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: I must and will, Sir, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke

l.seg: And so will I too, or it shall goe hard.—

sp.l: Farewell Mathias.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Farewell Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thus like the sad presaging Raven that tolls
The sicke mans passeport in her hollow beake,
And in the shadow of the silent night
Doth shake contagion from her sable wings;
Vex'd and tormented runnes poore Barabas
With fatall curses towards these Christians.
The incertaine uncertain pleasures of swift-footed time
Have tane their flight, and left me in despaire;
And of my former riches rests no more
But bare remembrance; like a souldiers skarre,
That has no further comfort for his maime.
Oh thou that with a fiery piller led'st
The sonnes of Israel through the dismall shades,
Light Abrahams off-spring; and direct the hand
Of Abigall this night; or let the day
Turne to eternall darkenesse after this:
No sleepe can fasten on my watchfull eyes,
Nor quiet enter my distemper'd thoughts,
Till I have answer of my Abigall.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Now have I happily espy'd a time
To search the plancke my father did appoint;
And here behold (unseene) where I have found
The gold, the perles, and Jewels which he hid.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Now I remember those old womens words,
Who in my wealth youthB (qy) wud tell me winters winter's S+ (-Dd3) winters' tales,
And speake of spirits and ghosts that glide by night
About the place where Treasure hath bin hid:
And now me thinkes that I am one of those:
For whilst I live, here lives my soules sole hope,
And when I dye, here shall my spirit walke.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Now that my fathers fortune were so good
As but to be about this happy place;
'Tis not so happy: yet when we parted last,
He said he wud attend me in the morne.
Then, gentle sleepe, where e're his bodie rests,
Give charge to Morpheus that he may dreame
A golden dreame, and of the sudden walke wake ,
Come and receive the Treasure I have found.

sp.speaker: Barabas

l.foreign:
Bien Birn para todos ,
mi my
ganado ga nada no es er :

sp.l: As good goe on, as sit so sadly thus.
But stay, what starre shines yonder in the East?
The Loadstarre of my life, if Abigall.
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Peace, Abigal, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Then father here receive thy happinesse.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Hast thou't?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Here,
Hast thou't?
There's more, and more, and more.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh my girle,
My gold, my fortune, my felicity;
Strength to my soule, death to mine enemy;
Welcome the first beginner of my blisse:
Oh Abigal Aigal Abigal, that I had thee here too,
Then my desires were fully satisfied,
But I will practice thy enlargement thence:
Oh girle, oh gold, oh beauty, oh my blisse!

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Father, it draweth towards midnight now,
And 'bout this time the Nuns begin to wake;
To shun suspition, therefore, let us part.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Farewell my joy, and by my fingers take
A kisse from him that sends it from his soule.
Now Phoebus ope the eye-lids of the day,
And for the Raven wake the morning Larke,
That I may hover with her in the Ayre ,
Singing ore these, as she does ore her young.

l.foreign:
Hermoso Placer Piarer
, de los les
Dineros Denireh .

div2.head: Act Two, Scene Two
div2.stage: Enter Governor, Martin del Bosco, the Knights [and Officers].

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now Captaine tell us whither thou art bound?
Whence is thy ship that anchors in our Rhoad?
And why thou cam'st ashore without our leave?

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: Governor of Malta, hither am I bound;
My Ship, the flying Dragon, is of Spaine,
And so am I, Delbosco is my name;
Vizadmirall unto the Catholike King.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: 'Tis true, my Lord, therefore intreat him well.

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: Our fraught freight is Grecians, Turks Grecians, Turkes , and Africk Moores Africk Moores .
For late upon the coast of Corsica,
Because we vail'd not to the Turkish Spanish Fleet,
Their creeping Gallyes had us in the chase:
But suddenly the wind began to rise,
And then we luft left , and tackt tooke , and fought at ease:
Some have we fir'd, and many have we sunke;
But one amongst the rest became our prize:
The Captain's slaine, the rest remaine our slaves,
Of whom we would make sale in Malta here.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Martin del Bosco, I have heard of thee;
Welcome to Malta, and to all of us;
But to admit a sale of these thy Turkes Turkes
We may not, nay we dare not give consent
By reason of a Tributary league.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: Delbosco, as thou lovest and honour'st us,
Perswade our Governor against the Turke Turke ;
This truce we have is but in hope of gold,
And with that summe he craves might we wage warre.

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: Will Knights of Malta be in league with Turkes Turkes ,
And buy it basely too for summes of gold?
My Lord, Remember that toEurop's shame,
The Christian Ile of Rhodes, from whence you came,
Was lately lost, and you were stated here
To be at deadly enmity with Turkes Turkes .

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Captaine we know it, but our force is small.

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: What is the summe that Calymath requires?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: A hundred thousand Crownes.

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: My Lord and King hath title to this isle,
And he meanes quickly to expell you them hence;
Therefore be rul'd by me, and keepe the gold:
I'le write unto his majesty for ayd,
And not depart untill I see you free.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: On this condition shall thy Turkes Turkes be sold.
Goe Officers and set them straight in shew.
Bosco, thou shalt be Malta's Generall;
We and our warlike Knights will follow thee
Against these barbarous mis-beleeving Turkes Turkes .

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: So shall you imitate those you succeed:
For when their hideous force inviron'd Rhodes,
Small though the number was that kept the Towne,
They fought it out, and not a man surviv'd
To bring the haplesse newes to Christendome.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: So will we fight it out; come, let's away:
Proud-daring Calymath, instead of gold,
Wee'll send thee bullets wrapt in smoake and fire:
Claime tribute where thou wilt, we are resolv'd,
Honor is bought with bloud and not with gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: This is the Market-place, here let 'em stand
Feare not their sale, for they'll be quickly bought.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: Every ones price is written on his backe,
And so much must they yeeld or not be sold.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: Here comes the Jew, had not his goods bin seiz'd,
He'de give given us present mony for them all.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: In spite of these swine-eating Christians,
(Unchosen Nation, never circumciz'd;

Such as, as
poore villaines, poor villains as poor villains such as were ne're thought upon
Till Titus and Vespasian conquer'd us) .)
Am I become as wealthy as I was:
They hop'd my daughter would ha bin a Nun;
But she's at home, and I have bought a house
As great and faire as is the Governors;
And there in spite of Malta will I dwell:
Having Fernezes hand, whose heart I'le have;
I, and his sonnes too, or it shall goe hard.
I am not of the Tribe of Levy, I,
That can so soone forget an injury.
We Jewes can fawne like Spaniels when we please;
And when we grin we bite, yet are our lookes
As innocent and aud harmelesse as a Lambes.
I learn'd in Florence how to kisse my hand,
Heave up my shoulders when they call me dogge,
And ducke as low as any bare-foot Fryar,
Hoping to see them starve upon a stall,
Or else be gather'd for in our Synagogue;
That when the offering-Bason comes to me,
Even for charity I may spit intoo't.
Here comes Don Lodowicke the Governor's sonne,
One that I love for his good fathers sake.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: I heare the wealthy Jew walked this way;
I'le seeke him out, and so insinuate,
That I may have a sight of Abigall;
For Don Mathias tels me she is faire.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Now will I shew my selfe to have more of the Serpent
then Then the Dove; that is, more knave than foole.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Yond walks the Jew, now for faire Abigall.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, I, no doubt but shee's at your command.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Barabas, thou know'st I am the Governors sonne.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
I wud you were his father too, Sir, that's al the harm I
wish you: the slave looks like a hogs cheek new sindg'd.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Whither walk'st thou, Barabas Barobas ?
No further: 'tis a custome held with us,
That when we speake with Gentiles Gentiles like to you,
We turne into unto the Ayre to purge our selves:
For unto us the Promise cloth belong.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Well, Barabas, canst helpe me to a Diamond?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh, Sir, your father had my Diamonds.
Yet I have one left that will serve your turne:

l.seg: I meane my daughter:—but e're he shall have her
I'le sacrifice her on a pile of wool.
I ha the poyson of the City for him,
And the white leprosie.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: What sparkle does it give without a foile?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: The Diamond that I talke of, ne'r was foild:

l.seg: But when he touches it, it he will be foild:

sp.l: Lord Lodowicke, it sparkles bright and faire.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Is it square or pointed, pray let me know.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Pointed it is, good Sir,—but not for you.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: I like it much the better.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: So doe I too.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: How showes it by night?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Outshines Cinthia's rayes:

l.seg: You'le like it better farre a nights than dayes.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: And what's the price?

sp.speaker: Barabas

l.seg: Your life and if you have it.—

sp.l: Oh my Lord we will not jarre about the price;
Come to my house and I will giv't your honour—

l.seg: With a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: No, Barabas, I will deserve it first.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Good Sir,
Your your father has deserv'd it at my hands,
Who of meere charity and Christian ruth truth ,
To bring me to religious purity,
And as it were in Catechising sort,
To make me mindfull of my mortall sinnes,
Against my will, and whether I would or no,
Seiz'd all I had, and thrust me out a doves,
And made my house a place for Nuns most chast.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: No doubt your soule shall reape the fruit of it.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, but my Lord, the harvest is farre off:
And yet I know the prayers of those Nuns
And holy Fryers, having mony for their paines,
Are wondrous; and indeed doe no man good:
And seeing they are not idle, but still doing,
'Tis likely they in time may reape some fruit,
I meane in fulnesse of perfection.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Good Barabas glance not at our holy Nuns.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, but I doe it through a burning zeale,

l.seg: Hoping ere long to set the house a fire;

sp.stage: Aside . Q places to right of line

l.seg: For though they doe a while increase and multiply,
I'le have a saying to that Nunnery.

sp.l: As for the that Diamond, Sir, I told you of,
Come home and there's no price shall make us part,
Even for your Honourable fathers sake.

l.seg: It shall goe hard but I will see your death.

sp.l: But now I must be gone to buy a slave.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: And, Barabas, I'le beare thee company.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Come then, here's the marketplace; whats the price of What price is on
this slave, two hundred Crowns? Do the Turkes Turke weigh so much?

sp.l: Sir, that's his price.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What, can he steale that you demand so much?
Belike he has some new tricke for a purse;
And if he has, he is worth three hundred 300 plats.
So that, being bought, the Towne-seale might be got
To keepe him for his life time from the gallowes.
The Sessions day is criticall to theeves,
And few or none scape but by being purg'd.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.p: Ratest thou this Moore Moore but at two hundred plats?

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.p: No more, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Why should this
Turke
be dearer then that Moore Moore ?
Because he is young and has more qualities.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
What, hast the Philosophers stone? and thou hast,
breake my head with it, I'le forgive thee.
No Sir, I can cut and shave.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Let me see, sirra, are you not an old shaver?
Alas, Sir, I am a very youth.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
A youth? I'le buy you, and marry you to Lady vanity,
if you doe well.
I will serve you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Some wicked trick or other. It may be under colour
of Of
shaving, thou'lt cut my throat for my goods.
Tell me, hast thou thy health well?
I, passing well.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
So much the worse; I must have one that's sickly, and and't an't
be but for sparing vittles: 'tis not a stone of beef a day will main-
taine you in these chops; let me see one that's somewhat leaner.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.p: Here's a leaner, how like you him?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Where was wastDd2-B (-D1) thou borne?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: In Trace; brought up in Arabia.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: So much the better, thou art for my turne . ,
An hundred Crownes, I'le have him; there's the coyne.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: Then marke him, Sir, and take him hence.

sp.speaker: Barabas

l.seg: I, marke him, you were best, for this is he
That by my helpe shall doe much villanie.

sp.l: My Lord farewell: Come Sirra you are mine.
As for the Diamond it shall be yours;
I pray, Sir, be no stranger at my house,
All that I have shall be at your command.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: What makes make the Jew and Lodowicke so private?
I feare me 'tis about faire Abigall.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Yonder comes Don Mathias, let us stay;
He loves my daughter, and she holds him deare:
But I have sworne to frustrate both their hopes,

And be reveng'd upon the —
Governor
.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: This Moore is comeliest, is he not? speake son.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: No, this is the better, mother, view this well.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Seeme not to know me here before your mother
Lest she mistrust the match that is in hand:
When you have brought her home, come to my house;
Thinke of me as thy father; Sonne farewell.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: But wherefore talk'd Von Lodowick with you?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Tush man, we talk'd of Diamonds, not of Abigal.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Tell me, Mathias, is not that the Jew?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: As for the Comment on the Machabees
I have it, Sir, and 'tis at your command.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Yes, Madam, and my talke with him was but but
About the borrowing of a booke or two.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Converse not with him, he is cast off from heaven.
Thou hast thy Crownes, fellow, come let's away.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Sirra, Jew, remember the booke books .

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Marry will I, Sir.
Come, I have made a reasonable market,
Lets away.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Now let me know thy name, and therewithall
Thy birth, condition, and profession.
Faith, Sir, my birth is but meane, my name's Ithimor,
My profession what you please.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Hast thou no Trade? then listen to my words,

And I will teach thee that shall sticke by thee
:
First be thou voyd of these affections,
Compassion, love, vaine hope, and hartlesse feare,
Be mov'd at nothing, see thou pitty none,
But to thy selfe smile when the Christians moane.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Oh brave, master, I worship your nose for this.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: As for my selfe, I walke abroad a nights
And kill sicke people groaning under walls:
Sometimes I goe about and poyson wells;
And now and then, to cherish Christian theeves,
I am content to lose some of my Crownes;
That I may, walking in my Gallery,
See 'em goe pinion'd along by my dove.
Being young I studied Physicke, and began
There I enrich'd enric'd the Priests with burials,
And alwayes kept the Sexton's armes in ure use
With digging graves and ringing dead mens keels:
And after that I was an Engineere,

And in the warres 'twixt
France
and Germanie,
Under presence of helping Charles the fifth,
Slew friend and enemy with my stratagems.
Then after that was I I was an Usurer,
And with extorting, cozening, forfeiting,
And tricks belonging unto Brokery,
I fill'd the Jailes with Bankrouts in a yeare,
And with young Orphans planted Hospitals,
And every Moone made some or other mad,
And now and then one hang himselfe for griefe,
Pinning upon his breast a long great Scrowle
How I with interest tormented him.
But marke how I am blest for plaguing them,
I have as much coyne as will buy the Towne.
But tell me now, How hast thou spent thy time?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Faith, Master,
In setting christian villages on fire,
Chaining of Eunuches, binding gally-slaves.
One time I was an Hostler in an Inne,

And in the night time secretly would I
steale
To travellers Chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneel'd,
I strowed powder on the Marble stones,
And therewithall their knees would ranckle, so
That I have laugh'd agood to see the cripples
Goe limping home to Christendome on stilts.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villaines both:
Both circumcized, we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret, thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside, here comes Don Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Oh Barabas well met;
Where is the Diamond you told me of?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I have it for you, Sir; please you walke in with me:
What, ho, Abigall; open the doore I say.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: In good time, father, here are letters come
From Ormus, and the Post stayes here within.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Give me the letters, daughter, doe you heare?
Entertaine Lodowicke the Governors sonne
With all the curtesie you can affoord;
Provided, that you keepe your Maiden-head.

Use him as if he were a —
Philistine.

l.seg: Dissemble, sweare, protest, vow to love love toD (qy) him,
He is not of the seed of Abraham.

sp.l: I am a little busie, Sir, pray pardon me.
Abigall, bid him welcome for my sake.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: For your sake and his own he's welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Daughter, a word more; kisse him, speake him faire,

l.seg: And like a cunning Jew so cast about,
That ye be both made sure e're you come out.
O father, Don Mathias is my love.

sp.speaker: Barabas

l.seg: I know it: yet I say make love to him;
Doe, it is requisite it should be so.

sp.l: Nay on my life it is my Factors hand,
But goe you in, I'le thinke upon the account:
The account is made, for Lodovico Lodowicke Lodowick he dyes.
My Factor sends me word a Merchant's fled
That owes me for a hundred Tun of Wine:
I weigh it thus much; I have wealth enough.
For now by this has he kist Abigall;
And she vowes love to him, and hee to her.
As sure as heaven rain'd Manna for the Jewes,
So sure shall he and Don Mathias dye:
His father was my chiefest enemie.
Whither goes Don Mathias? stay a while.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Whither but to my faire love Abigall?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thou know'st, and heaven can witnesse it this is true,
That I intend my daughter shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: I, Barabas, or else thou wrong'st me much.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh heaven forbid I should have such a thought.
Pardon me though I weepe; the Governors sonne
Will, whether I will or no, have Abigall:
He sends her letters, bracelets, jewels, rings.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Does she receive them?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Shee? No, Mathias, no, but sends them backe,
And when he comes, she lockes her selfe up fast;
Yet through the key-hole will he talke to her,
While she runs to the window looking out
When you should come and hale him from the doore.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Oh treacherous Lodowicke!

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Even now as I came home, he slips me in,
And I am sure he is with Abigall.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: I'le rouze him thence.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Not for all Malta, therefore sheath your sword;
If you love me, no quarrels in my house;
But steale you in, and seeme to see him not;
I'le give him such a warning e're he goes
As he shall have small hopes of Abigall.
Away, for here they come.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l:
What ,
hand in hand, I cannot suffer this.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Mathias, as thou lov'st me, not a word.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Well, let it passe, another time shall serve.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Barabas, is not that the widowes sonne?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, and take heed, for he hath sworne your death.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l:
My death? what ,
is the base borne peasant mad?

sp.speaker: Baratas
sp.l: No, no, but happily he stands in feare
Of that which you, I thinke, ne're dreame upon,
My daughter here, a paltry silly girle.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l:
Why ,
loves she Don Mathias?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Doth she not with her smiling answer you?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: He has my heart, I smile against my will.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Barabas, thou know'st I have lov'd thy daughter long.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: And so has she done you, even from a child.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: And now I can no longer hold my minde.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Nor I the affection that I beare to you.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: This is thy Diamond, tell me, shall I have it?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Win it, and weare it, it is yet unfoyl'd unfoil'd unsoyl'd .
Oh but I know your Lordship wud disdaine
To marry with the daughter of a Jew:
And yet yer I'le give her many a golden crosse
With Christian posies round about the ring.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke.
sp.l: 'Tis not thy wealth, but her that I esteeme,
Yet crave I thy consent.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: And mine you have, yet let me talke to her;

l.seg: This offspring of Cain, this Jebusite
That never tasted of the Passeover,
Nor e're shall see the land of Canaan,
Nor our Messias that is yet to come,
This gentle Magot, Lodowicke I meane,
Must be deluded: let him have thy hand,
But keepe thy heart till Don Mathias comes.
What, shall I be betroth'd to Lodowicke?

sp.speaker: Barabas

l.seg: For they themselves hold it a principle,
Faith is not to be held with Heretickes;
But all are Hereticks that are not Jewes;
This followes well, and therefore daughter feare not.

sp.l: I have intreated her, and she will grant.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Then gentle Abigal plight thy faith to me.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I cannot chuse, seeing my father bids: —
Nothing but death shall part my love and me.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Now have I that for which my soule hath long'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: So have not I, but yet I hope I shall.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Oh wretched Abigal, what hast thou thee done?

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Why on the sudden is your colour chang'd?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I know not, but farewell, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Stay her, —
but let her not speake one word more.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Mute a the sudden; here's a sudden change.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Oh muse not at it, 'tis the
Hebrewes
guize,
That maidens new betroth'd should weepe a while:
Trouble her not, sweet Lodowicke depart:
Shee is thy wife, and thou shalt be mine heire.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Oh, is't the custome, then I am resolv'd:
But rather let the brightsome heavens be dim,
And Natures beauty choake with stifeling clouds,
Then my faire Abigal should frowne on me.
There comes the villaine, now I'le be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Be quiet Lodowicke, it is enough
That I have made thee sure to Abigal.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: Well, let him goe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Well, but for me, as you went in at dores
You had bin stab'd, but not a word on't now;
Here must no speeches passe, nor swords be drawne.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: Suffer me, Barabas, but to follow him.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No; so shall I, if any hurt be done,
Be made an accessary of your deeds;
Revenge it on him when you meet him next.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: For this I'le have his heart.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Doe so; loe here I give thee Abigall.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: What greater gift can poore Mathias have?
Shall Lodowicke rob me of so faire a love?
My life is not so deare as Abigall.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: My heart misgives me, that to crosse your love,
Hee's with your mother, therefore after him.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: What, is he gone unto my mother?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Nay, if you will, stay till she comes her selfe.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: I cannot stay; for if my mother come,
Shee'll dye with griefe.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I cannot take my leave of him for teares:
Father, why have you thus incenst them both?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I'le make 'em friends againe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: You'll make 'em friends?
Are there not Jewes enow in Malta , .
But thou must dote upon a Christian?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I will have Don Mathias, he is my love.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Yes, you shall have him: Goe put her in.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: I, I'le put her in.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Now tell me, Ithimore, how lik'st thou this?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Faith Master, I thinke by this
You purchase both their lives; is it not so?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: True; and it shall be cunningly perform'd.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Oh, master, that I might have a hand in this.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, so thou shalt, 'tis thou must doe the deed:
Take this and beare it to Mathias streight,
And tell him that it comes from Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Tis poyson'd, is it not?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, no, and yet it might be done that way:
It is a challenge feign'd from Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Feare not, I'le so set his heart a fire,
That he shall verily thinke it comes from him.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I cannot choose but like thy readinesse:
Yet be not rash, but doe it cunningly.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: As I behave my selfe in this, imploy me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Away then.
So, now will I goe in to unto Lodowicke,
And like a cunning spirit feigne some lye,
Till I have set 'em both at enmitie.
Since this Towne was besieg'd, my gaine growes cold:
The time has bin, that but for one bare night
A hundred Duckets have bin freely given:
But now against my will I must be chast.
And yet I know my beauty doth not faire.
From Venice Merchants, and from Padua ,
Were wont to come rare witted Gentlemen,
Schollers I meane, learned and liberall;
And now, save Pilia-borza, comes there none,
And he is very seldome from my house;
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: Hold thee, wench, there's something for thee to spend.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: 'Tis silver, I disdaine it.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: I, but the Jew has gold,
And I will have it or it shall goe hard.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Tell me, how cam'st thou by this?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
Faith, walking the backe lanes through the Gardens
I chanc'd to cast mine eye up to the Jewes counting-house where
I saw some bags of mony, and in the night I clamber'd up with my
hooks, and as I was taking my choyce, I heard a rumbling in the
house; so I tooke onely this, and runne my way: but here's the
Jews man.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Hide the bagge.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: Looke not towards him, let's away:

Zoon's what a looking thou keep'st ,
thou'lt Thou'lt betraye's anon.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
O the sweetest face that ever I beheld! I know she is a
Curtezane by her attire: now would I give a hundred of the Jewes
Crownes that I had such snch a Concubine.
sp.l: Well, I have deliver'd the challenge in such sort,
As meet they will, and fighting dye; brave sport.

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: This is the place, now Abigall shall see
Whether Mathias holds her deare or no.

sp.speaker: Lodowicke
sp.l: What, dares the villain write to write in such base terms?

sp.speaker: Mathias
sp.l: I did it, and revenge it if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh bravely fought, and yet they thrust not home.
Now Lodowicke Lodovico , now and now Mathias, so;

So ,
now they have shew'd themselves to be tall fellowes.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Part 'em, part 'em.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, part 'em now they are dead: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What sight is this? my Lodovico Lodowicke Q, Dd2+ (-D) slaine!
These armes of mine shall be thy Sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Who is this; my sonne Mathias slaine!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Oh Lodowicke! hadst thou perish'd by the Turke,
Wretched Ferneze might have veng'd thy death.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Thy sonne slew mine, and I'le revenge his death.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Looke, Katherin, looke, thy sonne gave mine these wounds.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Oh leave to grieve me grive me , I am griev'd enough.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Oh that my sighs could turne to lively breath;
And these my teares to blood, that he might live.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Who made them enemies?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I know not, and that grieves me most of all.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: My sonne lov'd thine.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: And so did Lodowicke him.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Lend me that weapon that did kill my sonne,
And it shall murder me.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nay Madam Madem stay, that weapon was my son's,
And on that rather should Ferneze dye.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Hold, let's inquire the causers of their deaths,
That we may venge their blood upon their heads.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then take them up, and let them be interr'd
Within one sacred monument of stone;
Upon which Altar I will offer up
My daily sacrifice of sighes and teares,

And with my prayers pierce th'
impartiall heavens,

Till they reveal
discloseDd3 (qy) the causers of our smarts,
Which forc'd their hands divide united hearts:
Come, Katherine, our losses equall are,
Then of true griefe let us take equall share.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Why, was there ever seene such villany,
So neatly plotted, and so well perform'd?
Both held in hand, and flatly both beguil'd.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Why, how now Ithimore, why laugh'st thou so?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Oh, Mistresse, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Why what ayl'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Oh my master.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Oh Mistris! I have the bravest, gravest, secret, subtil,
bottle-nos'd knave to my Master, that ever Gentleman had.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Say, knave, why rail'st upon my father thus?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Oh, my master has the bravest policy.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Why, know you not?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l:
Why ,
no.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Know you not of Mathias Mathia and Don Lodowickes Lodowick disaster?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: No, what was it?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Why the devil invented a challenge, my master Mr. writ it,
and I carried it, first to Lodowicke, and imprimis to Mathias.
sp.l:
And then they met, and
as the story sayes,
In dolefull wise they ended both their dayes.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: And was my father furtherer of their deaths?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Am I Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: So sure did your father write, and I cary the chalenge.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Well, Ithimore, let me request thee this,
Goe to the new made Nunnery, and inquire
For any of the Fryars of Saint Jaques Jaynes ,
And say, I pray them come and speake with me.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I pray, mistris, wil you answer me to
but one question?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.p: Well, sirra, what is't?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
A very feeling one; have not the Nuns fine sport with
the Fryars now and then?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.p: Go to, sirra sauce, is this your question? get ye you gon.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: I will forsooth, Mistris.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Hard-hearted Father, unkind Barabas,
Was this the pursuit purpose of thy policie?
To make me shew them favour severally,
That by my favour they should both be slaine?
Admit thou lov'dst lovest not Lodowicke for his sire sinne ,
Yet Don Mathias ne're offended thee:
But thou wert set upon extreme revenge,
Because the Pryor Governor Sire dispossess thee once,
And couldst not venge it, but upon his sonne,
Nor on his sonne, but by Mathias meanes;
Nor on Mathias, but by murdering me.
But I perceive there is no love on earth,
Pitty in Jewes, nor or piety in Turkes.
But here comes Comes cursed Ithimore with the Fryar.
Virgo, Virgo.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l:
When ,
ducke you?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Welcome grave Fryar; Ithamore begon,
Know, holy Sir, I am bold to sollicite thee.
Wherein?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: To get me be admitted for a Nun.
Why Abigal it is not yet long since
That I did labour thy admition,
And then thou didst not like that holy life.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Then were my thoughts so fraile and unconfirm'd,
And I was chain'd to follies of the world:
But now experience, purchased with griefe,
Has made me see the difference of things.
My sinfull soule, alas, hath pac'd too long
The fatall Labyrinth of misbeleefe,
Farre from the Sonne son Dd2- sun that gives eternall life.
Who taught thee this?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: The Abbasse of the house
Whose zealous admonition I embrace:
Oh therefore, Jacomo Jacome , let me be one,
Although unworthy of that Sister-hood.
Abigal I will, but see thou change no more,
For that will be most heavy to thy soule.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: That was my father's fault.
Thy father's, how?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Nay, you shall pardon me: oh Barabas,
Though thou deservest hardly at my hands,
Yet never shall these lips bewray thy life.
Come, shall we goe?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: My duty waits on you.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What, Abigall become a Nunne againe?

False, and unkinde; what ,
hast thou lost thy father?
And all unknowne, and unconstrain'd of me,
Art thou againe got to the Nunnery?
Now here she writes, and wils me to repent.
Repentance? Spurca: what pretendeth portendeth this?
I feare she knowes ('tis so) of my device
In Don Mathias and Lodovicoes Lodowick's deaths:
If so, 'tis time that it be seene into:
For she that varies from me in beleefe
Gives great presumption that she loves me not;
Or loving, doth dislike of something done .

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: But who comes here? Oh Ithimore come neere;

Come neere ,
my love, come neere ,
thy masters life,
My trusty servant, nay, my second selfe life ;
For I have now no hope but even in thee;
And on that hope my happinesse is built:
When saw'st thou Abigall?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: To day.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: A Fryar.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: A Fryar? false villaine, he hath done the deed.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Why ,
made mine Abigall a Nunne.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: That's no Iye, for she sent me for him.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh unhappy day,
False, credulous, inconstant Abigall!
But let 'em goe: And Ithimore, from hence
Ne're shall she grieve me more with her disgrace;
Ne're shall she live to inherit ought of mine,
Be blest of me, nor come within my gates,
But perish underneath my bitter curse
Like Cain by Adam, for his brother's death.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Oh master.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Ithimore, intreat not for her, I am mov'd,
And she is hatefull to my soule and me:
And less less least thou yeeld to this that I intreat,
I cannot thinke but that thou hat'st my life.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Who I, master? Why I'le run to some rocke huge rock and throw
my selfe headlong into the sea; why I'le doe any thing for your
sweet sake.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh trusty lthimore; no servant, but my friend;
I here adopt thee for mine onely heire,
All that I have is thine when I am dead,
And whilst I live use halfe helfe ; spend as my selfe;
Here take my keyes, I'le give 'em thee anon.
Goe buy thee garments: but thou shalt not want:
Onely know this, that thus thou art to doe:
But first goe fetch me in the pot of Rice
That for our supper stands upon the fire.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: I hold my head my master's hungry: I goe Sir.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thus every villaine ambles after wealth
Although he ne're be richer then in hope:
But hush't.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Here 'tis, Master.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Well said, Ithimore;
What, hast thou brought the Ladle with thee too?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, the proverb saies, he that eats with the devil
had need of a long spoone. I have brought you a Ladle.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Very well, Ithimore, then now be secret;
And for thy sake, whom I so dearely love,
Now shalt thou see the death of Abigall,
That thou mayst freely live to be my heire.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Why, master, wil you poison her with a messe of rice
porredge ?
that wil preserve life, make her round and plump, and
batten more then you are aware.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I but Ithimore seest thou this?
It is a precious powder that I bought
Of an Italian Italian in Ancona once,
Whose operation is to binde, infect,
And poyson deeply: yet not appeare
In forty houres after it is tane.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: How master?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thus Ithimore:
This Even they use in Malta here ('tis call'd
Saint Jaques Jagues Even) and then I say they use
To send their Almes unto the Nunneries:
There's a darke entry where they take it in,
Where they must neither see the messenger,
Nor make enquiry who hath had sent it them.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Belike there is some Ceremony in't.
There Ithimore must thou goe place this pot plot :
Stay, let me spice it first.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Pray doe, and let me help you, master . Mr. Pray let me
taste first.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Prethe doe: what saist thou now?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Troth master , Mr. I'm loth such a pot of pottage should be
spoyld.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Peace, Ithimore, tis better so then spar'd.
Assure thy selfe thou shalt have broth by the eye.
My purse, my Coffer, and my selfe is shine.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Well, master, I goe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Stay, first let me stirre it Ithimore.
As fatall be it to her as the draught
Of which great Alexander drunke, and dyed:
And with her let it worke like Borgias wine,
Whereof his sire, the Pope, was poysoned poyson'd .
In few, the blood of Hydra, Lerna's Lerna's bane;
The jouyce of Hebon Hebon , and Cocitus breath,
And all the poysons of the Stygian poole
Breake from the fiery kingdome; and in this
Vomit your venome, and invenome her
That like a fiend hath left her father thus.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
What a blessing has he given't give'nt ? was ever pot of
rice porredge so sauc't? what shall I doe with it?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh my sweet Ithimore go set it downe
And come againe so as soone as thou hast done,
For I have other businesse for thee.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Here's a drench to poyson a whole stable of Flanders
mares: I'le carry's to the Nuns with a powder.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: And the horse pestilence to boot; away.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: I am gone.
Pay me my wages for my worke is done.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Ile pay thee with a vengeance lthamore.

div2.head: Act Three, Scene Five
div2.stage: Enter Governor, Bosco, Knights, [Callapine, the] Bashaw.]

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p:
Welcome, great Bashaw Bashaws Bashaw , how fares Callymath,
what wind drives you thus thus drives you into Malta rhode?

sp.l: The wind that bloweth all the world besides,
Desire of gold.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Desire of gold, great Sir?
That's to be gotten in the Westerne Inde:
In Malta are no golden Minerals.
To you of Malta thus saith Calymath:
The time you tooke for respite, is at hand,
For the performance of your promise past;
And for the Tribute-mony I am sent.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Bashaw Bashaw , in briefe, shalt have no tribute here,
Nor shall the Heathens live upon our spoyle:
First will we race the City wals our selves,
Lay waste the Iland, hew the Temples downe,
And shipping of our goods to Sicily,
Open an entrance for the wastfull sea,
Whose billowes beating the resistlesse bankes,
Shall overflow it with their refluence.
Well, Governor, since thou hast broke the league
By flat denyall of the promis'd Tribute,
Talke not of racing downe your City wals,
You shall not need trouble your selves so farre,
For Selim-Calymathshall come himselfe,
And with brasse-bullets batter downe your Towers,
And turne proud Malta to a wildernesse
For these intolerable wrongs of yours;
And and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Farewell:
And now you ye men of Malta looke about,
And let's provide to welcome Calymath:
Close your Port-cullise, charge your Basiliskes,
And as you profitably take up Armes,
So now couragiously encounter them;
For by this Answer, broken is the league,
And nought is to be look'd for now but warres,
And nought to us more welcome is then wars.

div2.head: Act Three, Scene Six
div2.stage: Enter [the] two Fryars Fryars and Abigall .

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: Oh brother, brother, all the Nuns are sicke,
And Physicke will not helpe them; they must dye.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: The Abbasse sent for me to be confest:
Oh what a sad confession will there be?

sp.speaker: 1. Fryer
sp.l: And so did faire Maria send for me:
I'le to her lodging; hereabouts she lyes.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: What, all dead save onely Abigall?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: And I shall dye too, for I feele death comming.
Where is the Fryar that converst with me?

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: Oh he is gone to see the other Nuns.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I sent for him, but seeing you are come
Be you my ghostly father; and first know,
That in this house I liv'd religiously,
Chast, and devout, much sorrowing for my sinnes,
But e're I came—

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: I did offend high heaven so grievously,
As I am almost desperate for my sinnes:
And one offence torments me more then all.
You knew Mathias and Don Lodowicke?

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: Yes, what of them?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: My father did contract me to 'em both:
First to Don Lodowicke, him I never lov'd;
Mathias was the man that I held deare,
And for his sake did I become a Nunne.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: So, say how was their end?

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: Both jealous of my love, envied each other:
And by my father's practice, which is there
Set downe at large, the Gallants were both slaine.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: Oh monstrous villany.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: To worke my peace, this I confesse to thee;
Reveale it not, for then my father dyes.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: Know that Confession must not be reveal'd,
The Canon Law forbids it, and the Priest
That makes it knowne, being degraded first,
Shall be condemn'd, and then sent to the fire.

sp.speaker: Abigall
sp.l: So I have heard; pray therefore keepe it close . ,
Death seizeth on my heart : , ah gentle Fryar ,
Convert my father that he may be sav'd,
And witnesse that I dye a Christian.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: I, and a Virgin too, that grieves me most:
But I must to the Jew and exclaime on him,
And make him stand in feare of me.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: Oh brother, all the Nuns are dead, let's bury them.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar.
sp.l: First helpe to bury this, then goe with me
And helpe me to exclaime against the Jew.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l: Why? what has he done?

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: A thing that makes me tremble to unfold.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryar
sp.l:
What ,
has he crucified a child?

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: No, but a worse thing: 'twas told me in shrift,
Thou know'st 'tis death and if it be reveal'd.
Come let's away.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: There is no musicke to like a Christians knell:
How sweet the Bels ring now the Nuns are dead
That sound at other times like Tinkers pans?
I was afraid the poyson had not wrought;
Or though it wrought, it would have done no good,
For every yeare they swell, and yet they live;
Now all are dead, not one remaines alive.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: That's brave, master , Mr. but think you it wil not be known ?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: How can it if we two be secret.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: For my part feare you not.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I'de cut thy throat if I did.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: And reason too;
But here's a royall Monastry hard by,
Good master let me poyson all the Monks.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thou shalt not need, for now the Nuns are dead.
They'll dye with griefe.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Doe you not sorrow for your daughters death?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, but I grieve because she liv'd so long .
An Hebrew Hebrew bome, and would become a Christian ? .

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Look, look, master , Mr. here come comes two religious Caterpillers.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I smelt 'em e're they came.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: God-a-mercy nose; come let's begone.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryer
sp.l: Stay wicked Jew, repent, I say, and stay.

sp.speaker: 1. Fryer
sp.l: Thou hast offended, therefore and therefore must be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I feare they know we sent the poyson'd broth.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: And so doe I, master, therefore speake 'em faire.
Barabas, thou hast—
I, that thou hast—

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: True, I have mony, what though I have?
Thou art a—
I, that thou art a—

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What needs all this? I know I am a Jew.
Thy daughter—
I, thy daughter , —
