sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh speake not of her, then I dye with griefe.
Remember that—
I, remember that—

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I must needs say that I have beene a great usurer.
Thou hast committed—

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Fornication? but that was in another Country:
And besides, the Wench is dead.
I, but Barabas, remember Mathias and Don Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why, what of them?
I will not say that by a forged challenge they met.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: She has confest, and we are both undone,
My bosome inmate inmates intimates , but I must dissemble.
Oh holy Fryars, the burthen of my sinnes
Lye Lies heavy on my soule; then pray you tell me,
Is't not too late now to turne Christian?
I have beene zealous in the Jewish faith,
Hard harted to the poore, a covetous wretch,
That would for Lucars sake have sold my soule.
A hundred for a hundred I have tane;
And now for store of wealth may I compare
With all the Jewes in Malta but what is wealth?
I am a Jew, and therefore am I lost.

Would pennance any penance
serve serve to atone for this my sinne,
I could afford to whip my selfe to death.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: And so could I; but pennance will not serve.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: To fast, to pray, and weare a shirt of haire,
And on my knees creepe to Jerusalem . ,
Cellers of Wine, and Sollers full of Wheat,
Ware-houses stuft with spices and with drugs,
Whole Chests of Gold, in Bullion Bulloine , and in Coyne,
Besides I know not how much weight in Pearle
Orient and round, have I within my house;
At Alexendria, Merchandize unsold untold :
But yesterday two ships went from this Towne,
Their voyage will be worth ten thousand Crownes.
In Florence, Venice, Antwerpe, London, Civill,
Frankeford, Lubecke, Mosco, and where not,
Have I debts owing; and in most of these,
Great summes of mony lying in the bancho;
All this I'le give to some religious house
So I may be baptiz'd and live therein.
Oh good Barabas come to our house.
Oh no, good Barabas come to our house.
And Barabas, you know—

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I know that I have highly sinn'd,

l.seg: You shall convert me, you shall have all my wealth.

sp.l: Oh Barabas, their Lawes are strict.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I know they are, and I will be with you.
They weare no shirts, and they goe bare-foot too.

l.seg: Then 'tis not for me; and I am resolv'd
You shall confesse me, and have all my goods.

sp.speaker: 2. Fryar
sp.l: Good Barabas, come to me.

l.seg: You see I answer him, and yet he stayes;
Rid Bid him away, and goe you home with me.

sp.l: I'le be with you to night.

l.seg: Come to my house at one a clocke this night.

sp.l: You heare your answer, and you may be gone.

Why goe ,
get you away.
I will not goe for thee.
Not ? , then I'le make thee, rogue rogue goe .
How, cost call me rogue?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Part 'em, master, part 'em.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: This is meere frailty, brethren, be content.
Fryar Barnardine goe you with Ithimore.

l.seg: You Ith. you know my mind, let me clone with him.

sp.l: Why does he goe to thy house? let him begone.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I'le give him something and so stop his mouth.
I never heard of any man but he
Malign'd the order of the Jacobines:
But doe you thinke that I beleeve his words?
Why, Brother, you converted Abigall;
And I am bound in charitie to requite it,
And so I will, oh Jacomo, faile not but come.
But Barabas, who shall be your godfathers,
For presently you shall be shriv'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Marry the Turke Turke shall be one of my godfathers,
But not a word to any of your Covent.
I warrant thee, Barabas.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
So ,
now the feare is past, and I am safe:
For he that shriv'd her is within my house . ,
What if I murder'd him e're Jacomo Jocoma comes?
Now I have such a plot for both their lives,
As never Jew nor Christian knew the like:
One turn'd my daughter, therefore he shall dye;
The other knowes enough to have my life,
Therefore 'tis not requisite he should live.
But are not both these wise men to suppose
That I will leave my house, my goods, and all,
To fast and be well whips; I'le none of that.
Now Fryar Bernardine I come to you,
I'le feast you, lodge you, give you faire words,
And after that, I and my trusty Turke—
No more but so: it must and shall be done. Exit
Ithimore, tell me, is the Fryar asleepe?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Yes; and I know not what the reason is : .
Doe what I can he will not strip himselfe,
Nor goe to bed, but sleepes in his owne clothes;
I feare me he mistrusts what we intend.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, 'tis an order which the Fryars use:
Yet if he knew our meanings, could he scape?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: No, none can heare him, cry he ne're so loud.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Why true, therefore did I place him there:
The other Chambers open towards the street.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: You loyter, master, wherefore stay we me thus?
Oh how I long to see him shake his heeles.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Come on, sirra,

Fryar ,
awake.

What ,
doe you meane to strangle me?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Yes, 'cause you use to confesse.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Blame not us but the proverb, Confes and be hang'd .
Pull hard.
What, will you have have save my life?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Pull hard, I say, you would have had my goods.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: I, and our lives too, therefore pull amaine.
'Tis neatly done, Sir, here's no print at all.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Then is it it is as it should be, take him up.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Nay, master, be rul'd by me a little; so, let him leane
upon his staffe; excellent, he stands as if he were begging of for
Bacon.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Who would not thinke but that this Fryar liv'd?
What time a night is't now, sweet Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Towards one.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Then will not Jacomo be long from hence.
This is the houre
Wherein I shall proceed; Oh happy houre,
Wherein I shall convert an Infidell,
And bring his gold into our treasury.
But soft, is not this Bernardine? it is;
And understanding I should come this way,
Stands here a on purpose, meaning me some wrong,
Away, I'de wish thee, and let me goe by:
No, wilt thou not? nay then I'le force my way;
And see, a staffe stands ready for the purpose:
As thou lik'st that, stop me another time.

div2.stage: Strike him, he fals. Enter [come forward] Barabas [and Ithimore].

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Why ,
how now Jacomo Jocoma , what hast has thou done?

Why ,
stricken him that would have stroke at me.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Who is it ?
Bernardine? now out alas,
He is slaine.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I, master Mr. , he's slain; look how his brains drop out on's
nose.

Good sirs I have don't, but no body knowes it but you
two, I may escape.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: So might my man and I hang with you for company.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: No, let us beare him to the Magistrates.
Good Barabas let me goe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, pardon me, the Law must have his its course.
I must be forc'd to give in evidence,
That being importun'd by this Bernardine
To be a Christian, I shut him out,
And there he sate: now I to keepe my word,
And give my goods and substance to your house,
Was up thus early; with intent to goe
Unto your Friery, because you staid.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Fie upon 'em, master Mr. , will you turne Christian, when
holy Friars turne devils and murder one another.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, for this example I'le remaine a Jew:
Heaven blesse me; what, a Fryar a murderer?
When shall you see a Jew commit commit it the like?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Why, a Turke could ha done no more.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: To morrow is the Sessions; you shall to it.
Come Ithimore, let's helpe to take him hence.
Villaines, I am a sacred person, touch me not.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: The Law shall touch you, we'll but lead you, we:
'Las I could weepe at your calamity.
Take in the staffe too, for that must be showne:
Law wils that each particular be knowne.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Pilia-borza, didst thou meet with Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: And didst thou deliver my letter?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: And what think'st thou, will he come?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
I think so, and but yet I cannot tell, for at the reading
of the letter, he look'd like a man of another world.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
That such a base slave as he should be saluted by
such a tall man as I am, from such a beautifull dame as you.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: And what said he?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
Not a wise word, only gave me a nod, as who shold
say, Is it even so; and so I left him, being driven to a non- plus at
the critical aspect of my terrible countenance.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: And where didst meet him?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
Upon mine my owne free hold within fortie 40
foot feet of the
gallowes, conning his neck-verse I take it, looking of a Fryars
Execution, whom I saluted with an old hempen proverb, Hodie
tibi, cras mihi, and so I left him to the mercy of the Hangman:
but the Exercise being done, see where he comes.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I never knew a man take his death so patiently as this
Fryar: he was ready to leape off e're the halter was about his
necke; and when the Hangman had put on his hempen Tippet,
he made such haste to his prayers, as if hee had had another
Cure to serve; well, goe whither he will, I'le be none of his
followers in haste:
And now I thinke on's, going to the execution, a fellow met me
with a muschatoes mustachios Dd2- like a Ravens wing, and a Dagger with a
hilt like a warming-pan, and he gave me a letter from one
Madam Bellamira, saluting me in such sort as if he had
meant to
make cleane my Boots with his lips; the effect was, that I should
come to her house . , I wonder what the reason is .
It may be she
sees more in me than I can find in my selfe: for she writes further,
that she loves me ever since she saw me, and who would not
requite such love? here's her house, and here she comes, and now
would I were gone, I am not worthy to looke upon her.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: This is the Gentleman you writ to.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Gentleman, he flouts me, what gentry can be in a
poore
Turke of ten pence? I'le be gone. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Is't not a sweet fac'd youth, Pilia?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Agen, sweet youth; did not you, Sir, bring the sweet
youth a letter?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
I did Sir, and from this Gentlewoman, who as my
selfe, and the rest of the family, stand or fall at your service.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p:
Though womans modesty should hale me backe,
I can with-hold no longer; welcome sweet love.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Now am I cleane, or rather fouly out of the way.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Whither so soone?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I'le goe steale some mony from my Master to make
me hansome: [Aside.]
Pray pardon me, I must goe see and see a ship discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Canst thou be so unkind to leave me thus?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: And ye you did but know how she loves you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Nay, I care not how much she loves me;
sp.l: Sweet Bellamira Allamira , would I had my Masters wealth for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: And you can have it, Sir, and if you please.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
If 'twere above ground I could, and would have it; but
tree hides and buries it up as Partridges doe their egges, under the
earth.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: And is't not possible to find it out?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: By no meanes possible.

l.seg: What shall we doe with this base villaine then?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza

l.seg: Let me alone, doe but you omit speake him faire:

sp.l: But you know But you know sirD (qy) But, sir, you know some secrets of the Jew,
Which if they were reveal'd, would doe him harme.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: I, and such as— Goe to, no more,
I'le make him send me half he has, and glad he scapes so too.
Pen and Inke Pen and Inke :
I'le write unto him, we're have mony strait.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: Send for a hundred Crownes at least.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Ten hundred thousand crownes, Master Mr. Barabas.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: Write not so submissively, but threatning threaten him.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Sirra Barabas, send me a hundred crownes.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Put in two hundred at least.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I charge thee send me three hundred 300 by this bearer, and
this shall be your warrant; if you doe not, no more but so.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Tell him you will confesse.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Otherwise I'le confesse all :— ,
sp.l: Vanish and returne in a twinckle.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Let me alone, I'le use him in his kinde.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Hang him ,
Jew.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Now, gentle Ithimore, lye in my lap.
Where are my Maids? provide a running cunning Banquet;
Send to the Merchant, bid him bring me silkes,
Shall Ithimore my love goe in such rags?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: And bid the Jeweller come hither too.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: I have no husband, sweet, I'le marry thee.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Content, but we will leave this paltry land,
And saile from hence to Greece, to lovely Greece,
I'le be thy Jason, thou my golden Fleece;
Where painted Carpets o're the meads are hurl'd,
And Bacchus vineyards over ore -spread the world:
Where Woods and Forrests goe in goodly greene,
I'le be Adonis, thou shalt be Loves Queene.
The Meads, the Orchards, and the Primrose lanes,
Instead of Sedge and Reed, beare Sugar Canes:
Thou in those Groves, by Dis above,
Shalt live with me and be my love.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Whither Whiiher will I not goe with gentle Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: How now? hast thou the gold?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
But came it freely, did the Cow give down her milk
freely?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
Ithimore
sp.p: Rather for feare then love.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
Then like a Jew he laugh'd and jeer'd, and told me
he lov'd me for your sake, and said what a faithfull servant you
had bin.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: The more villaine he to keep me thus:
sp.l: Here's goodly 'parrell, is there not?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: To conclude, he gave me ten crownes.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
But ten? I'le not leave him worth a gray groat . ,
Give give me
a Reame of paper, we'll have a kingdome of gold for't.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Write for five hundred 500 Crownes.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Sirra Jew, as you love your life send me five hundred 500
crowns, and give the Bearer one hundred a hundred 100 . Tell him I must hav't.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: I warrant your worship shall hav't.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
And if he aske why I demand so much, tell him, I
scorne to write a line under a hundred crownes.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: You'd make a rich Poet, Sir. I am gone.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Take thou the mony, spend it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p:
Tis not thy mony, but thy selfe I weigh:
Thus See thus Bellamira esteemes of gold; [Throw it aside.]
But thus of thee .—

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
That kisse againe; she runs division of my lips. What
an eye she casts on me? It twinckles like a Starre.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Come my deare love, let's in and sleepe together.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Oh that ten thousand nights were put in one,
That wee might sleepe seven yeeres together afore
w We wake.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Come Amorous wag, first banquet and then sleep.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Barabas send me three hundred 300 Crownes.
Plaine Barabas: oh that wicked Curtezane Curtezane !
He was not wont to call me Barabas.
Or else I will confesse: I, there it goes:

But if I get him ,
Coupe de le Gorge , for that .
He sent a shaggy totter'd staring slave,
That when he speakes, drawes out his grisly beard,
And winds it twice or thrice about his eare;
Whose face has bin a grind-stone for mens swords,
His hands are hacks, some fingers cut quite off;
Who when he speakes, grunts like a hog, and looks
Like one that is imploy'd in Catzerie,

And crosbiting ,
such a Rogue sort of rogue
As is the husband to a hundred whores:
And I by him must send three hundred crownes.
Well, my hope is, he will not stay there still;
And when he comes: oh that he were but here!

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Jew, I must ha more gold.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Why ,
wantst thou any of thy tale?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: No; but three hundred 300 will not serve his turne.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Not serve his turne, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: No Sir; and therefore I must have five hundred 500 more.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: I'le rather—

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
Oh good words, Sir, and send it you, weere best se;
there's his letter.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Might he not as well come as send; pray bid him come
and fetch it : , what tree writes for you, ye shall have streight.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: I, and the rest too, or else—

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
I must make this villaine away: please you dine with me,
Sir, and you shal be most hartily poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: No god-a-mercy, shall I have these crownes?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I cannot doe it, I have lost my keyes.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Oh, if that be all, I can picke ope your locks.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Or climbe up to my Counting-house window: you know
my meaning.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
I know enough, and therfore talke not to me of your
Counting -house: , the gold, or know Jew it is in my power to
hang thee.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I am betraid .— ,
'Tis not five hundred Crownes that I esteeme,
I am not mov'd at that: this angers me,
That he who knowes I love him as my selfe
Should write in this imperious vaine ! ? why Sir,
You know I have no childe, and unto whom
Should I leave all but unto Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Here's many words but no crownes; the crownes.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Commend me to him, Sir, most humbly,
And unto your good mistris as unknowne.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Speake, shall I have 'um, Sir?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Sir, here they are.

l.seg: Oh that I should e'er shouldD (qy) part with so much gold!

sp.l: Here take 'em, fellow, with as good a will—
— As I wud see thee hang'd; oh, love stops my breath:
Never lov'd man servant as I doe Ithimore.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: I know it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Pray when, Sir, shall I see you at my house?

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Soone enough to your cost, Sir:
sp.l: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Nay to
thine owne cost, villaine, if thou com'st.
Was ever Jew tormented as I am?

To have a shag-rag knave to come demand
and force from me force from me convey
Three hundred 300 Crownes, and then five hundred 500 Crownes?
Well, I must seeke a meanes to rid 'em all,
And presently: for in his villany
He will tell all he knowes and I shall dye for't.
I have it.
I will in some disguize goe see the slave,
And how the villaine revels with my gold.

div2.head: Act Four, Scene Four

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: I'le pledge thee, love, and therefore drinke it off.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Saist thou me so? have at it; and doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Goe to, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Of that condition I wil drink it up; here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Nay, I'le have all or none.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: There, if thou lov'st me doe not leave a drop.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Love thee, fill me three glasses.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Three and fifty dozen, I'le pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: Knavely spoke, and like a Knight at Armes.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Hey Rivo Castiliano, a man's a man.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Now to the Jew.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l:
Ha ,
to the Jew, and send me mony you he were best.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.l: What wudst thou doe if he should send thee none?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l:
Doe ?
nothing; but I know what I know . ,
He's a murderer.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: I had not thought he had been so brave a man.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
You knew Mathias and the Governors son ; , he and I
kild 'em both, and yet never touch'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Oh bravely done.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I carried the broth that poyson'd the Nuns, and he
and I ,
snicle snickle
hand hard
too to and
fast fist fist , strangled a Fryar.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: You two alone ? .

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
We two, and 'twas never knowne, nor never shall be But
for me.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: This shall with me unto the Governor.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: And fit it should: but first let's ha more gold.
Come gentle Ithimore, lye in my lap.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Love me little, love me long, let musicke rumble,
Whilst I in thy incony incoomy lap doe tumble.

div2.stage: Enter Barabas with a Lute, disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: A French Musician, come let's heare have your skill?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Must tuna my Lute for sound, twang twang first.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Wilt drinke French-man, here's to thee with a—pox on
this drunken hick-up.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Gramercy Mounsier.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p:
Prethe, Pilia-borza, bid the Fidler give me the posey
in his hat there.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Sirra, you must give my mistris your posey.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: How sweet, my Ithimore, the flowers smell.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Like thy breath, sweet-hart, no violet like 'em.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Foh, me thinkes they stinke like a Holly-Hoke.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: So, now I am reveng'd upon 'em all.
The scent thereof was death, I poyson'd it.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Play, Fidler, or I'le cut your cats guts into chitterlins.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
Pardona moy, be no in tune yet; so ,
now, now all be in.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: Give him a crowne, and fill me out more wine.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: There's two crownes for thee, play.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: How liberally the villian gives me mine own gold.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Me thinkes he fingers very well.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: So did you when you stole my gold.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: How swift he runnes.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
You yon
run ran swifter when you yon threw my gold out of my
sp.l: Window.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Musician, hast beene in Malta long?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Two, three, foure month Madam.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: Dost not know a Jew, one Barabas?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Very mush, Mounsier, you no be his man ? .

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: His man?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: I scorne the Peasant, tell him so.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: He knowes it already.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Tis a strange thing of that Jew, he lives upon pickled
Grashoppers, and sauc'd Mushrumbs.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p:
What a slave's this?
The Governour feeds not as I doe.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: He never put on a cleane shirt since he was circumcis'd.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Oh raskall! I change my selfe twice a day.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p: The Hat he weares, Judas left under the Elder when he hang'd himselfe.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: 'Twas sent me for a present from the great Cham.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: A masty nasty musty slave he is . ;
sp.l: Whether now, Fidler?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Pardona moy, Mounsier, me we be no well.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Farewell Fidler: One letter more more letter to the Jew.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.p: Prethe sweet love, one more, and write it sharp.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
No, I'le send by word of mouth now;
Bid him deliver thee a thousand Crownes, by the same token, that
the Nuns lov'd Rice, that Fryar Bernardine slept in his owne
clothes . ,
Any of 'em will doe it.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p: Let me alone to urge it now I know the meaning.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.l: The meaning has a meaning; come let's in:
To undoe a Jew is charity, and not sinne.

div2.stage: Enter Governor, Knights, Martin Del Bosco.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now, Gentlemen, betake you to your Armes,
And see that Malta be well fortifi'd;
And it behoves you to be resolute;
For Calymath having hover'd here so long,
Will winne the Towne, or dye before the wals.
And dye he shall, for we will never yeeld.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Oh bring us to the Governor.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Away with her, she is a Curtezane.

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: What e're I am, yet Governor heare me speake;
I bring thee the newes by whom thy sonne was slaine:
Mathias did it not, it was the Jew.

sp.speaker: Pilia-borza
sp.p:
Who, besides the slaughter of these Gentlemen,
poyson'd his owne daughter and the Nuns, strangled a Fryar,
and I know not what mischiefe beside.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Had we but proofe of this — .

sp.speaker: Curtezane
sp.l: Strong proofe, my Lord, his man's now at my lodging
That was his Agent, he'll confesse it all.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Goe fetch him 'emD (qy) straight . ,
I alwayes fear'd that Jew.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
I'le goe alone, dogs ,
do not hale me thus.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Nor me neither, I cannot out-run you Constable, oh
my belly.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: One dram of powder more had made all sure . ,
What a damn'd slave was I?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Make fires, heat irons, let the racke be fetch'd.

sp.l: Nay stay, my Lord, 'tmay be he will confesse.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Confesse; what meane you, Lords, who should confesse?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Thou and thy Turk; 'twas you thou that slew my son.

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
Gilty, my Lord, I confesse; your sonne and Mathias
were both contracted unto Abigall ; ,
he
forg'd a counterfeit
challenge.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: Who carried that challenge?

sp.speaker: Ithimore
sp.p:
I carried it, I confesse, but who writ it?
Marry, even he that strangled Bernardine, poyson'd the Nuns, and
his owne daughter.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Away with him, his sight is death to me.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: For what ? , you men of Malta, heare me speake;
Shee is a Curtezane and he a theefe,
And he my bondman, let me have law,
For none of this can prejudice my life.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Once more away with him; you shall have law.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Devils doe your worst, I'le IDd2+ (-D) live in spite of you.
As these have spoke so be it to their soules: —
I hope the poyson'd flowers will worke anon.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Was my Mathias murder'd by the Jew?
Ferneze, 'twas it was thy sonne that murder'd him.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Be patient, gentle Madam, it was he,
He forged the daring challenge made and made them fight.

sp.speaker: Mater
sp.l: Where is the Jew, where is that murderer?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: In prison till the Law has past on him.
My Lord, the Curtezane and her man are dead; so
So is the Turke, and Barabas the Jew.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Dead?
Dead, my Lord, and here they bring his body.

sp.speaker: Bosco
sp.l: This sudden death of his is very strange.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Wonder not at it, Sir, the heavens are just:
Their deaths were like their lives, then think not of 'em:
Since they are dead, let them be buried.
For the Jewes body, throw that o're the wals,
To be a prey for Vultures and wild beasts.
So, now away and fortifie the Towne.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What, all alone? well fare sleepy drinke.
I'le be reveng'd on this accursed Towne;
For by my meanes Calymath shall enter in.
I'le helpe to slay their children and their wives,
To fire the their Churches, pull their houses downe,
Take my goods too, and seize upon my lands:
I hope to see the Governour a slave,
And, rowing in a Gally, whips to death.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Whom have we there here , a spy?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Yes, my good Lord, one that can spy a place
Where you may enter, and surprize the Towne:
My name is Barabas; I am a Jew.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Art thou that Jew whose goods we heard were sold
For Tribute-mony?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: The very same, my Lord:

And since that time they have
hir'd a slave my man
To accuse me of a thousand villanies:
I was imprison'd, but escap'd scap'd their hands.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Didst breake prison?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.p: No, no:
sp.l: I dranke of Poppy and cold mandrake juyce;
And being asleepe, belike they thought me dead,
And threw me o're the wals: so, or how else,
The Jew is here, and rests at your command.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: 'Twas bravely done: but tell me, Barabas,
Canst thou, as thou reportest, make Malta ours?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l:
Feare not, my Lord, for here ,
against the sluice sluice Truce trench ,
The rocke is hollow, and of purpose digg'd,
To make a passage for the running streames
And common channels of the City.
Now whilst you give assault unto the wals,
I'le lead five hundred 500 souldiers through the Vault,
And rise with them i'th middle of the Towne,
Open the gates for you to enter in,
And by this meanes the City is your owne.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: If this be true, I'le make thee Governor.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: And if it be is not true, then let me dye.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Thou'st doom'd thy selfe, assault it presently.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Two
div2.stage: Alarmes. Enter Turkes, Barabas, Governour, and Knights prisoners.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Now vaile your pride you captive Christians,
And kneele for mercy to your conquering foe:
Now where's the hope you had of haughty Spaine?
Ferneze, speake, had it not beene much better

To To've T'have To have
keep kept thy promise then be thus surpriz'd?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What should I say ? , we are captives and must yeeld.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: I, villains, you must yeeld, and under Turkish yokes
Shall groping beare the burthen of our ire;
And Barabas, as erst we promis'd thee,
For thy desert we make thee the Governor,
Use them at thy discretion.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Thankes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l:
Oh fatall day ,
to fall into the hands hand
Of such a Traitor and unhallowed Jew!
What greater misery could heaven inflict?

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: 'Tis our command: and Barabas we give
To guard thy person, these our Janizaries:
Intreat them well, as we have used thee.
And now, brave Bashawes, come, wee'll walke about
The ruin'd Towne, and see the wracke we made:
Farewell brave Jew, farewell great Barabas.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: May all good fortune follow Calymath.
And now, as entrance to our safety,
To prison with the Governour and these
Captaines, his consorts and confederates.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Oh villaine, Heaven will be reveng'd on thee.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Away, no more, let him not trouble me.
Thus hast thou gotten, by thy policie,
No simple place, no small authority,
I now am Governour of Malta; true,
But Malta hates me, and in hating me
My life's in danger, and what boots it thee
Poore Barabas, to be the Governour,
When as thy life shall be at their command ?
No, Barabas, this must be look'd into;
And since by wrong thou got'st Authority,
Maintaine it bravely by firme policy,
At least unprofitably lose it not:
For he that liveth in Authority,
And neither gets him friends, nor fils his bags,
Lives like the Asse that Aesope speaketh of,
That labours with a load of bread and wine,
And leaves it off to snap on Thistle tops:
But Barabas will be more circumspect.
Begin betimes, Occasion's bald behind,
Slip not shine opportunity, for feare too late
Thou seek'st for much, but canst not compasse it .
Within here.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: My Lord ?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: I, Lord, thus slaves will learne.

Now Governor —
stand by there, wait within .— ,
This is the reason that I sent for thee;
Thou seest thy life, and Malta's happinesse,
Are at my Arbitrament; and Barabas
At his discretion may dispose of both:
Now tell me, Governor, and plainely too,
What thinkst thou shall become of it and thee?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I see no reason but of Malta's wracke,
Nor hope of thee but extreme cruelty,
Nor feare I death, nor will I flatter thee.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Governor, good words, be not so furious;
'Tis not thy life which can availe me ought,
Yet you doe live, and live for me you shall:
And as for Malta's ruine, thinke you not
'Twere slender policy for Barabas
To dispossesse himselfe of such a place?
For sith, as once you said, within 'tis in this Ile
In Malta here, that I have got my goods,
And in this City still have had successe,
And now at length am growne your Governor,
Your selves shall see it shall not be forgot:
For as a friend not knowne, but in distresse,
I'le reare up Malta now remedilesse.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Will Barabas recover Malta's losse?
Will Barabas be good to Christians?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: What wilt thou give me, Governor, to procure
A dissolution of the slavish Bands
Wherein the Turke hath yoak'd your land and you?
What will you give me if I render you
The life of Calymath, surprize his men,
And in an out-house of the City shut
His souldiers, till I have consum'd 'em all with fire?
What will you give him that procureth this?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Doe but bring this to passe which thou pretendest,
Deale truly with us as thou intimatest,
And I will send amongst the Citizens
And by my letters privately procure
Great summes of mony for thy recompence:
Nay more, doe this, and live thou Governor still.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Nay, doe thou this, Ferneze, and be free;
Governor, I enlarge thee, live with me,
Goe walke about the City, see thy friends:
Tush, send not letters to 'em, goe thy selfe,
And let me see what mony thou canst make;
Here is my hand that I'le set Malta free:
And thus we cast it: To a solemne feast
I will invite young Selim-Calymath,
Where be thou present onely to performe
One stratagem that I'le impart to thee,
Wherein no danger shall betide thy life,
And I will warrant Malta free for ever.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Here is my hand, beleeve me, Barabas,
I will be there, and doe as thou desirest;
When is the time?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Governor, presently.
For Callymath, when he hath view'd the Towne,
Will take his leave and saile toward , Ottoman.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then will I, Barabas, about this coyne,
And bring it with me to thee in the evening.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Doe so, but faire not; now farewell Ferneze:
And thus farre roundly goes the businesse:
Thus loving neither, will I live with both,
Making a profit of my policie;
And he from whom my most advantage comes,
Shall be my friend.
This is the life we Jewes are us'd to lead;
And reason too, for Christians doe the like:
Well, now about effecting this device:
First to surprize great Selims souldiers,
And then to make provision for the feast,
That at one instant all things may be done,
My policie detests prevention:
To what event my secret purpose drives,
I know; and they shall witnesse with their lives.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Thus have we view'd the City, scene the sacke,
And caus'd the wines to be new repair'd,
Which with our Bombards shot and Basiliske basiliskes ,
We rent in sunder at our entry:
And now I see the Scituation,
And how secure this conquer'd Iland stands
Inviron'd with the mediterranean Sea,
Strong contermin'd countermur'd with other petty Iles;

And toward Calabria ,
back'd by Sicily,
Where When Siracusian Dionisius reign'd ,
Two lofty Turrets that command the Towne.
I wonder how it could be conquer'd thus?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: From Barabas, Malta's Governor, I bring
A message unto mighty Calymath;
Hearing his Soveraigne was bound for Sea,
To saile to Turkey, to great Ottoman Ottamon ,
He humbly would intreat your Majesty
To come and see his homely Citadell,
And banquet with him e're thou leav'st the Ile.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: To banquet with him in his Citadell ? ,
I feare me, Messenger, to feast my traine
Within a Towne of warre so lately pillag'd,
Will be too costly and too troublesome:
Yet would I gladly visit Barabas , .
For well has Barabas deserv'd of us.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Selim, for that, thus saith the Governor,
That he hath in in his store a Pearle so big,
So precious, and withall so orient,
As be it valued but indifferently,
The price thereof will serve to entertaine
Selim and all his souldiers for a month;
Therefore he humbly would intreat your Highnesse
Not to depart till he has feasted you.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: I cannot feast my men in Malta wals,
Except he place his Tables in the streets.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Know, Selim, that there is a monastery
Which standeth as an out-house to the Towne;
There will he banquet them, but thee at home,
With all thy Bashawes Bashawes and brave followers.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Well, tell the Governor we grant his suit,
Wee'll in this Summer Evening feast with him.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I shall, my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: And now, bold Bashawes Bashawes , let us to our Tents,
And meditate how we may grace us best
To solemnize our Governors great feast.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: In this, my Countrimen, be rul'd by me,
Have speciall care that no man sally forth
Till you shall heare a Culverin discharg'd
By him that beares the Linstocke, kindled thus;
Then issue out and come to rescue me,
For happily I shall be in distresse,
Or you released of this servitude.
Rather then thus to live as Turkish thrals,
What will we not adventure?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: On then, begone.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight
sp.l: Farewell grave Governor.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Five
div2.stage: Enter [Barabas] with a Hammar above, very busie.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: How stand the cords? How hang these hinges, fast?
Are all the Cranes and Pulleyes sure?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: All fast.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Leave nothing loose, all leveld to my mind.
Why now I see that you have Art indeed.
There, Carpenters, divide that gold amongst you:
Goe swill in bowles of Sacke and Muscadine:
Downe to the Celler, taste of all my wines.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: We shall, my Lord, and thanke you.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: And if you like them, drinke your fill and dye:
For so I live, perish may all the world.

Now Selim-Calymath ,
returne me word
That thou wilt come, and I am satisfied.
Now sirra, what, will he come?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: He will; and has commanded all his men
To come ashore, and march through Malta streets,
That thou maist feast them in thy Citadell.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Then now are all things as my wish wud have 'em,
There wanteth nothing but the Governors pelfe,
And see he brings it: Now, Governor, the summe ? .

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: With free consent a hundred thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Pounds saist thou, Governor, wel since it is no more
I'le satisfie my selfe with that; nay, keepe it still,
For if I keepe not promise, trust not me.
And Governour, now partake take my policy:
Enter'd the Monastery, and underneath
In severall places are field-pieces pitch'd,
Bombards, whole Barrels full of Gunpowder,
That on the sudden shall dissever it,
And batter all the stones about their eares,
Whence none can possibly escape alive:
Now as for Calymath and his consorts,

Here have I made a
dainty Gallery,
The floore whereof, this Cable being cut,
Doth fall asunder; so that it doth sinke
Into a deepe pit past recovery.
Here, hold that knife, and when thou seest he comes,
And with his Bashawes shall be blithely set,
To give thee knowledge when to cut the cord,
And fire the house; say, will not this be brave?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Oh excellent! here, hold thee, Barabas,
I trust thy word, take what I promis'd thee.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: No, Governor, I'le satisfie thee first,
Thou shalt not live in doubt of any thing.
Stand close, for here they come:
Why why , is not this
A kingly kinde of trade to purchase Townes
By treachery, and sell 'em by deceit?
Now tell me, worldlings, underneath the sunne summe ,
If greater falshood ever has bin done.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Come, my Companion-Bashawes, see I pray
How busie Barabas is there above
To entertaine us in his Gallery;
Let us salute him . , Save thee, Barabas.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Welcome great Calymath.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: How the slave jeeres at him?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Will't please thee, mighy Selim-Calymath,
To ascend our homely stayres?

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: I, Barabas, come Bashawes, attend ascend .

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Stay, Calymath;
For I will shew thee greater curtesie
Then Barabas would have affoorded thee.

rdg.wit: R C B M K Ri

sp.p: Sound a charge there.

div2.stage: A charge, the cable cut, a Caldron discovered. [Barabas falls into it. Enter del Bosco and Knights.]

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: How now, what means this ?

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Helpe, helpe me, Christians, helpe.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: See Calymath, this was devis'd for thee.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l:
Treason, treason !
Bashawes, flye.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Selim, doe not flye;
See his end first, and flye then if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: Oh helpe me, Selim, helpe me, Christians.
Governour, why stand you all so pittilesse?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Should I in pitty of thy plaints or thee,

Accursed Barabas , ; base Jew ,
relent ? ;
No, thus I'le see thy treachery repaid,
But wish thou hadst behav'd thee otherwise.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: You will not helpe me then?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, villaine, no.

sp.speaker: Barabas
sp.l: And villaines, know you cannot helpe me now.
Then Barabas breath forth thy latest fate hate ,
And in the fury of thy torments, strive
To end thy life with resolution:
Know, Governor, 'twas I that slew thy sonne;
I fram'd the challenge that did make them meet:
Know, Calymath, I aym'd thy overthrow,
And had I but escap'd this stratagem,
I would have brought confusion on you all,
Damn'd Christians , Christian dogges, and Turkish Infidels;
But now begins the extremity of heat
To pinch me with intolerable pangs:
Dye life, flye soule, tongue curse thy fill and dye.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Tell me, you Christians, what doth this portend?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: This traine he laid to have intrap'd thy life;
Now Selim note the unhallowed deeds of Jewes:
Thus he determin'd to have handled thee,
But I have rather chose to save thy life.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Was this the banquet he prepar'd for us?
Let's hence, lest further mischiefe be pretended.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nay, Selim, stay, for since we have thee here,
We will not let thee part so suddenly:
Besides, if we should let thee goe, all's one,
For with thy Gallyes couldst thou not get hence,
Without fresh men to rigge and furnish them.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Tush, Governor, take thou no care for that,
My men are all aboord,
And doe attend my comming there by this.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Why, hardst thou not the trumpet sound a charge?

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l:
Why ,
then the house was fir'd,
Blowne up, and all thy souldiers massacred.

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l: Oh monstrous treason!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: A Jewes curtesie:
For he that did by treason worke our fall,
By treason hath delivered thee to us:
Know therefore, till thy father hath made good
The ruines done to Malta and to us,
Thou canst not part: for Malta shall be freed,
Or Selim ne're returne to Ottoman Ottamen .

sp.speaker: Calymath
sp.l:
Nay rather, Christians, let me goe to
Turkey
,
In person there to mediate mediate meditate your peace;
To keepe me here will nought advantage you.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Content thee, Calymath,here thou must stay,
And live in Malta prisoner; for come all call the world
To rescue thee, so will we guard us now,
As sooner shall they drinke the Ocean dry,
Then conquer Malta, or endanger us.
So march away, and let due praise be given
Neither to Fate nor Fortune Fottune , but to Heaven.
